TossDetails: India Won The Toss And Elected To Field
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
CompetitionName: India Tour Of Zimbabwe T20I Series 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
Just a week following their T20 World Cup triumph, the men in blue set off on a new journey, this time under the leadership of Shubman Gill, with VVS Laxman accompanying him as coach. Team India is scheduled to face Zimbabwe in a 5-match T20 series, with Sikandar Raza captaining the opposing team. Following the retirements of Virat Kohli, Rohit Sharma, and Ravindra Jadeja, the team is entering a transition phase, offering young and promising talents like Riyan Parag, Harshit Rana, Abhishek Sharma, and others the opportunity to display their skills in the blue jersey. The next generation of the Indian team will be eager to step up and replicate their impressive domestic performances on the international stage. Meanwhile, Zimbabwe, having missed out on a T20 World Cup spot, will be looking to secure some victories against this youthful Indian side.

Head to Head :

 

 

PITCH REPORT: 
Tino Mawoyo: " There is a slight covering of grass, which will dry out quickly. The surface is expected to remain consistent throughout the game and is considered a good batting wicket. Although the average score at Harare in the last 10-12 games has been around 150, that total likely won't be sufficient on this pitch."

 

 

TOSS:
India has won the toss and has elected to  first

 

Shubman Gill, Indian Skipper: "We will bowl first. The pitch seems favourable, and it should remain consistent throughout the game. This victory has been a long time coming; winning an ICC event after 11 years is a significant achievement. There are always expectations you set for yourself. We have three players making their debuts today: Sharma, Jurel, and Parag."

 

Sikandar Raza, Zimbabwe Skipper: "I don't mind batting first. The pitch looks favourable. Zimbabwe Cricket has entrusted me with guiding the team through this transition phase. I expect the young players to step up and show their determination. It's an honour to lead this group. With Sean's retirement, we have a young squad, and Ervine will play a significant role in the future."
PostMatchCommentary:

Zimbabwe emerged victorious by 13 runs. Batting first, Zimbabwe scored 115 for 9 in their 20 overs. Madhevere contributed 21 runs from 22 balls, and Brian Bennett added 22 runs from 15 balls. Captain Raza scored 17 runs from 19 balls, while Dion Myers chipped in with 23 runs from 22 balls. Clive Madande was the top scorer with an unbeaten 29 runs from 25 balls. For India, Ravi Bishnoi was the standout bowler, claiming 4 wickets for 13 runs in his 4 overs. Washington Sundar also impressed with figures of 2 for 11 from his 4 overs.

In response, India was bowled out for 102 in 19.5 overs. Shubman Gill top-scored with 31 runs from 29 balls, and Washington Sundar made 27 runs from 34 balls. However, the rest of the batting lineup struggled, with only Avesh Khan (16 runs from 12 balls) and Ravi Bishnoi (9 runs from 8 balls) reaching notable scores. For Zimbabwe, Raza led the bowling attack with 3 wickets for 25 runs, while Chatara picked up 3 wickets for 16 runs, helping Zimbabwe secure a 13-run win.

 

Shubman Gill, Indian Skipper: "We bowled pretty well, but we let ourselves down in the field. Our performance wasn't up to standard, and everyone seemed a bit rusty. We had discussed taking our time and enjoying our batting, but it didn't turn out that way. By the halfway mark, we had lost 5 wickets. It would have been ideal if I had stayed till the end, so I am very disappointed with how I got out and how the rest of the match unfolded. There was a glimmer of hope for us, but when you're chasing 115 and your number 10 batter is out there, you know something has gone wrong."
 

 

Sikandar Raza is Player of the Match 
 

Sikandar Raza, Zimbabwe Skipper: "I feel really happy about the win. We need to take it one game at a time because the job is not done and the series is not over. World champions play like world champions, so we need to be ready for the next game. This isn't a wicket where you get bowled out for 115, so credit to the bowlers of both sides. It's clearly an indication that we need to up our skills. I said I don't care about the result as long as we stay true to the crowd and the changing room. We had our plans, we stuck to them, and we backed our guys. Our catching and ground fielding were amazing, but we did make some errors, which shows there's room for improvement. We knew the fans would lift us up and give us energy, and credit to them—it really helped us."

PreMatchCommentary:
Hello and welcome to the live coverage of the second match between India and Zimbabwe. In the previous encounter, the hosts secured a win, defeating India by 13 runs. The second T20 match will be held at the same venue, with Shubman Gill's team aiming to bounce back from the loss and deliver a strong performance against a confident Zimbabwe side led by Sikandar Raza.

 

 

Head to Head :

 

PITCH REPORT: 
Tino Mawoyo & Abhinav Mukund: "The pitch is the same as yesterday's, where the Indian players had difficulty adapting to the conditions. Spinners targeted the good length area, and most wickets were taken from a back of a length on this pitch. When the ball is pitched fuller, batting becomes much easier."

 

 

TOSS:
India has won the toss and has elected to first

 

 

Shubman Gill, Indian Skipper: "We have decided to bat first on the same wicket as yesterday. It looks dry and the weather is nice and sunny, making it an ideal opportunity for us to bat. We need to improve our batting performance. Sudharsan is coming in for Khaleel."

 

 

Sikandar Raza, Zimbabwe Skipper: "It appears to be a summer wicket, and the pitch is expected to improve as the game progresses. We intended to bowl first regardless. The atmosphere in the changing room is relaxed and upbeat. We're taking it one game at a time, focusing on our purpose here and aiming to complete our task. Blessing has been impressive, and Chatara consistently performs well for us, delivering reliable results for the team."

In the second T20 between India and Zimbabwe, India batted first and amassed 234 for 2 in their 20 overs. Shubman Gill, the captain, departed early, but that did not slow down Abhishek Sharma. Sharma played a brilliant innings, scoring 100 runs off 47 balls with 7 fours and 8 sixes before being caught by Myers off Masakadza. Ruturaj Gaikwad remained unbeaten with 77 runs off 47 balls, hitting 11 fours and 1 six, while Rinku Singh also stayed not out, smashing 48 runs off 22 balls with 2 fours and 5 sixes.

In response, Zimbabwe was all out for 134 in 18.4 overs. Wessly Madhevere was the top scorer with 43 runs off 39 balls. The Indian bowlers kept constant pressure on the hosts, maintaining control over their scoring rate. Mukesh Kumar and Avesh Khan were the most successful bowlers, each taking three wickets. Ravi Bishnoi claimed two wickets, while Washington Sundar took one. 

 

 

Sikandar Raza, Zimbabwe Skipper: "The world champions will ultimately perform like world champions. Dropping catches today impacted us. I anticipated a score of 200 on this pitch, but they ended up with 30 runs more. Before this game, I thought it would be a tight match, but it didn't turn out that way as our top-order struggled. He has shown tremendous growth, demonstrating a strong desire to succeed, and his performance will keep improving. This is something we've been addressing for a long time; today, we came in with a positive mindset and played our shots."
 

 

Abhishek Sharma is the Player of the Match 

Abhishek Sharma: "I think my performance today was quite good, especially considering the tough defeat we faced yesterday. I felt that today was my day, and I made it count. In T20 cricket, it's all about momentum, and I carried it through to the end. Special thanks to the coach and team management for their support. As a youngster, it's important to express yourself when you have the opportunity. We were discussing after every ball, and he encouraged me to take charge and go for it."

 

Shubman Gill, Indian Skipper: "I'm very happy to be back to winning ways. Abhishek and Rutu's batting was exceptional, especially considering the challenging powerplay with the ball moving around. Yesterday, our issue was more about handling the pressure, which was tough for our young team experiencing their first international exposure. We still have three matches to go. It's always better to have more options than to be limited in choices."

PreMatchCommentary:
Ladies and gentlemen, we're poised for a cracker of a contest at Harare Sports Club! The five-match T20I series between India and Zimbabwe hangs in the balance at 1-1, setting the stage for a pivotal third encounter.After a shock upset in the opener, the Men in Blue roared back with a clinical 100-run demolition job. Now, with the series on a knife-edge, both sides are pulling out all the stops.

 

India's camp is buzzing with the return of their T20 World Cup heroes - the explosive Yashasvi Jaiswal, the dynamic Sanju Samson, and the hard-hitting Shivam Dube. Skipper Shubman Gill finds himself in the enviable position of having to juggle a star-studded lineup. Meanwhile, Zimbabwe's talismanic leader Sikandar Raza is rallying his troops, determined to recapture their early series magic.

The Indian think tank faces some delicious dilemmas. Will we see Jaiswal unleashed at the top, reshuffling the batting order? Samson's likely to don the gloves, adding his wealth of experience behind the stumps. And let's not forget Dube - a genuine game-changer with both bat and ball.

Zimbabwe, however, are grappling with consistency woes. The promising duo of Wessly Madhevere and Brian Bennett have shown glimpses of brilliance, but the hosts desperately need a collective effort to topple the Indian juggernaut. Their bowling unit, after being taken to the cleaners last time out, must channel the spirit of their opening match heroics.

Casting our minds back to the previous encounter, it was a masterclass from India. Abhishek Sharma and Ruturaj Gaikwad put on a batting clinic, their 137-run partnership forming the backbone of India's mammoth 234/2. Abhishek's scintillating century was the highlight, while Gaikwad's composed fifty provided the perfect foil.

Zimbabwe's reply, sadly, never got out of first gear.India's bowlers had a field day, with Mukesh Kumar and Avesh Khan landing the knockout blows, ably supported by the spin duo of Ravi Bishnoi and Washington Sundar.

As we look ahead to this crucial fixture, India's reinforcements add an extra layer of intrigue. Will they stick with the winning combination or unleash their returning stars?

Who will seize the momentum in this seesaw battle? Will it be India's firepower or Zimbabwe's home advantage that proves decisive? The anticipation is palpable as we count down to what promises to be a humdinger at Harare Sports Club. Buckle up - we're in for a treat! 



TOSS UPDATE: India Won the Toss and Elected to Bat   

Shubman Gill | India Captain: "We will bat first. Looks like a good wicket, no moisture, so that's why.We have got three World Cup winners back in the team: Sanju Samson, Yashasvi Jaiswal, and Shivam Dube. We are rotating our pacers, so Mukesh has been rested. Khaleel Ahmed is in." 
 

Sikandar Raza | Zimbabwe Captain: "We were going to bowl first anyway. A couple of changes for us. Richard Ngarava has been deemed fit and is back in the XI. Innocent Kaia, who split his webbing in the previous game, is out of the XI. Marumani is also in the side."

What a thrilling match! India, led by the dynamic Shubman Gill, secured a 23-run victory over Zimbabwe in the third match, taking a 2-1 lead in the series. Opting to bat first, India posted 182/4, thanks to Gill's stellar 66 off 49 balls and Ruturaj Gaikwad's explosive 49 off 28 balls. Yashasvi Jaiswal contributed 36 off 27 balls, with late cameo from Sanju Samson. Zimbabwe's bowlers Blessing Muzarabani and Sikandar Raza took 2 wickets each but faced resistance from the Indian batsmen. Chasing 183, Zimbabwe's top order crumbled to 39/5, but Dion Myers' unbeaten 65 off 49 balls showed resilience. Clive Madande and Wellington Masakadza added support, but it was insufficient as they ended at 159/6. Washington Sundar starred with the ball, claiming 3 wickets for 15 runs, supported by Avesh Khan's 2 wickets and Khaleel Ahmed's economical spell. Key moments included Gill and Gaikwad's 72-run partnership and Sundar's crucial breakthroughs. India's comprehensive performance leaves Zimbabwe needing a strong comeback in the next match. Stay tuned as the series heats up! 

 

Sikandar Raza| Zimbabwe Captain:"Yeah, I think it's our fielding again. We pride ourselves on our fielding, but the wheels have come off in the last few games. If we had fielded well, we would have been in the game. We also have issues at the top of the order that need fixing.Unfortunately, we've tried 15 different opening pairs, but nothing has clicked. It's time for the players, myself included, to step up and take responsibility. I can understand mistakes from youngsters, but some of us have played over 40 T20Is, and we need to shoulder the responsibility.I'm an option for the top order, but we also need some experience in the middle order. This is the best team we have, and we need to back them" 

Player of the Match - Washington Sundar

Washington Sundar :"Feels amazing. To perform for the country is always special. Yes, it feels amazing. It was definitely a better wicket today. In the first two matches, there was something in it for the bowlers. Today, it was much better for batting. Zimbabwe did put a bit of pressure on us. That partnership between Myers and Madande put some pressure on us, but we are happy to go over the line. We have plenty of places to visit here in Zimbabwe. Hopefully, we finish the series on Saturday." 



Shubman Gill | India Captain:"Feels good going 2-1 up in the series. It was a crucial game for us. Yeah, definitely, it looked like we would go over 200. It was not easy to hit the length ball, and that's what Ruturaj and I were discussing in the middle. That was the message we gave to our bowlers, and they executed it perfectly.Everyone is contributing, from the openers to the bowlers. It makes the job easier."

CompetitionName: India Tour Of Zimbabwe T20I Series 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
In the penultimate clash of the T20I series at Harare Sports Club, India looks to seal the series, leading 2-1 against Zimbabwe. After an unexpected hiccup in the opener, India bounced back with two emphatic victories, flexing their cricketing muscle and depth. The return of Yashasvi Jaiswal, Sanju Samson, and Shivam Dube from the T20 World Cup squad has added firepower to the team. Skipper Shubman Gill has been a rock at the top, and the middle order has fired on all cylinders, making India a formidable opponent. In the last game, India posted a competitive 182/4, thanks to solid contributions from Gill, Jaiswal, and a brisk cameo by Samson. Despite being a bit of a circus in the field, Zimbabwe managed to recover from a dismal 39/5 to 159/6, with Dion Myers and Clive Madande putting on a brave 77-run stand. However, their performance still fell short, with glaring fielding and batting inconsistencies. As we gear up for the fourth T20I, Zimbabwe faces a must-win scenario. They must sharpen their fielding and deliver a cohesive performance to stay in the hunt. India, brimming with confidence, aims to wrap up the series. With a pitch likely to favour spinners, expect some fireworks. Will Zimbabwe level the series and keep the dream alive, or will India crush their hopes? Buckle up, fans, for an epic showdown!

Head to Head :


PITCH REPORT:

Tino Mawoyo and Abhinav Mukund: "Today's game will be played on a fresh pitch. During our inspection, we noticed that the groundsmen had watered it yesterday, which means there might be some early moisture to assist the pacers. The pitch retains a bit more grass than usual. One boundary is quite short, measuring in the 60s, while the opposite side is longer, around the 80s. Indian pacers, known for their skiddy nature, have been effective at hitting the good length. Conversely, Zimbabwe's taller bowlers can exploit fuller lengths and generate bounce. Spinners will also find some assistance. Although Zimbabwe has started to read Bishnoi and Sundar better as the series has progressed, there’s still a lot of work ahead. This looks like the best pitch of the series so far."


TOSS: INDIA WON THE TOSS AND ELECTED TO FIELD!

 

Shubman Gill (India Captain): "We've decided to bowl first. The pitch seems fresh and from what the groundsmen mentioned, it’s been watered and should offer something for the fast bowlers. There are areas we need to improve, particularly in controlling the runs during the death overs. We got a bit complacent last time, so we'll be focusing on tightening up in that aspect. Tushar makes his debut."

 

Sikandar Raza (Zimbabwe Captain): "Our plan was to bat first today. Although the pitch is fresh, it tends to slow down later on in this region, so batting first seemed ideal. We're building towards our vision for 2026, and it's fantastic to have India here giving our players valuable game time. I'm hopeful our top three will make a strong start today. We need all three departments to perform well. If we can achieve that, we stand a good chance. After two tough games, I believe the team is eager and ready to bounce back."

The young Indian squad has proven too formidable for the Sikandar Raza-led Zimbabwe team, dominating the match comprehensively. Shubman Gill, continuing his winning streak at the toss, chose to bowl first on a fresh pitch. Tushar Deshpande, making his debut, and Khaleel Ahmed struggled initially with the new ball as Tadiwanashe Marumani and Wessly Madhevere forged a 63-run partnership for the first wicket. However, India's fifth and sixth bowlers, Abhishek Sharma and Shivam Dube, dismissed Marumani (32 off 31) and Madhevere (25 off 24) in consecutive overs, bringing India back into the contest. Zimbabwe lost momentum as wickets fell steadily. Nevertheless, skipper Sikandar Raza opted for an aggressive approach, scoring 46 off 28 balls, Once Raza was dismissed in the 19th over, India restricted Zimbabwe to 152/7 on a promising batting surface. Khaleel Ahmed rebounded effectively in the death overs, finishing with figures of 2/32. Tushar Deshpande claimed his first international wicket by dismissing the key player, Raza. Sundar, Abhishek, and Dube each took a wicket, while Bishnoi remained wicketless for the second game in a row. In response, Yashasvi Jaiswal and Shubman Gill launched a relentless assault on the Zimbabwean bowlers, forging an unbroken 156-run partnership. Jaiswal was the more aggressive, scoring 93 off 53 balls with 13 fours and 2 sixes. Gill, after a cautious start, found his rhythm and notched up his second consecutive fifty of the series, remaining unbeaten on 58 off 39 balls with 5 fours and 2 sixes. Zimbabwe's six bowlers were unable to break through and were thoroughly outplayed.

 

Sikandar Raza (Zimbabwe Captain): "I believe the pitch was a bit on the slower side at the start, perhaps slightly damp. We aimed for a total around 160, which we thought would be competitive, but credit where it's due – their batting was exceptional today. Even 180 might not have been sufficient. Today, we must acknowledge that they outplayed us with the bat. We aim to come back stronger in the final game of the series. We need to improve in all three areas of the game. Even if we end the series at 2-3, it would still be a respectable outcome."

 

Yashasvi Jaiswal (Player of the Match): "I thoroughly enjoyed today. The pitch was favourable, and I had specific plans for each bowler which made my batting experience enjoyable. When the ball was new, it came onto the bat nicely. But as it aged, it slowed down. I adjusted my approach accordingly. Shubman and I have great chemistry while batting together. Initially, I aimed to go hard in the first 10 overs, but after spending some time in the middle, I understood how to adapt and stay unbeaten till the end to secure the win for our team."

 

Shubman Gill (India Captain): "I’m thrilled with my first series win as captain, but the job isn’t finished yet. We still have one more game to play. Chasing was a key focus for us, and it's great to have accomplished that. This team is fantastic, a wonderful group of players. I hope we can continue to progress together. I haven’t had a discussion with the coach about any changes yet, but if there are any, I’ll update you at the toss."

TossDetails: Zimbabwe Won The Toss And Elected To Field

CompetitionName: India Tour Of Zimbabwe T20I Series 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
India is all set for a rapid turnaround as they gear up for the fifth and final T20I against Zimbabwe at the Harare Sports Club on Sunday, July 14. After a shocking loss in the series opener, the Shubman Gill-led Indian team has bounced back with a vengeance, winning the next three games to secure a 3-1 lead in the five-match series.

The latest victory was particularly emphatic, as India steamrolled Zimbabwe by 10 wickets, marking their dominance in the shortest format. Gill's impeccable record at the toss continued as he opted to bowl first in the fourth game. The Zimbabwean openers, Wessly Madhvere and Tadiwanashe Marumani, provided a sturdy start, but the middle order crumbled under pressure. Despite a valiant 46-run effort from Sikandar Raza, the hosts could only muster 152/7 in their 20 overs.

Tushar Deshpande, playing his debut series, redeemed himself with the crucial wicket of Raza after a shaky start. Khaleel Ahmed shone in the death overs, claiming two wickets, while Abhishek Sharma and Shivam Dube also chipped in with vital breakthroughs. Washington Sundar continued his consistent performance, and despite going wicketless, Ravi Bishnoi made an impact with his fielding prowess.

India's chase was a masterclass in batting. Yashasvi Jaiswal and Shubman Gill dismantled the Zimbabwean bowling attack with ease, guiding their team to victory in just 16 overs. Jaiswal's explosive 53-ball 93 and Gill's elegant 39-ball 58 ensured India reached the target without losing a wicket.

Looking ahead to the final game, India is expected to rotate their squad, possibly giving a chance to some new faces. The aim will be to finish the series on a high note with a 4-1 victory. Zimbabwe, on the other hand, will be playing for pride, hoping to salvage a win and end the series on a positive note.

Will India maintain their dominance, or can Zimbabwe pull off an upset in the final match?

Toss:- Zimbabwe have won the toss and opted to bowl first.

Sikandar Raza: "We're going to bowl first. The pitch tends to improve, so it should be better for batting in the second innings. We have the motivation, confidence, and skills needed. Chatara has been rested for this match".

Shubman Gill: "We were planning to bat first anyway. Our spinners have performed well, and the fast bowlers have been economical. The players are hungry and eager to play. It's challenging to play back-to-back matches. We have a couple of changes today - Mukesh Kumar and Parag are coming in."

India clinched the series 4-1 with a 42-run victory in the final T20I against Zimbabwe. put into bat first, India posted a competitive 167/6 in their allotted 20 overs. Sanju Samson stepped up when it mattered most, scoring a composed 58 off 45 balls. He was well-supported by Riyan Parag and Shivam Dube, who contributed 22 and 26 runs respectively, propelling India to a strong total.

In response, Zimbabwe struggled against India's bowling attack. Mukesh Kumar was the standout performer, claiming four crucial wickets. Despite an important 34-run knock from Myers and a late cameo from Faraz Akram, Zimbabwe fell short, managing only 125 runs before being bowled out. Shivam Dube also chipped in with two key wickets, ensuring India's dominance throughout the match.

This comprehensive win not only secured the series for India but also showcased the depth and resilience of their squad

Shivam Dube- Player of the Match: "Contributing in both batting and bowling is always special. Taking wickets felt great. T20s can be challenging, but one good shot can turn things around. The ground here is big, and we love playing in this amazing atmosphere with such fantastic people."

Washington Sundar- Player of the Series: "It's great to finish with a win. After the first game, we noticed conditions were similar to South Africa, with extra bounce and pace. We had plenty of time to gather insights. There are many takeaways and learnings from this series, and I got to bowl a lot. Our team had a lot of success together."

Sikandar Raza: "Blessing bowled excellently throughout the series. However, our batting fell short. What stands out for me is our fielding attitude, which we can improve. Richie wasn’t fit at the beginning, so having him fit now is fantastic. It's great to see Richie and Blessing working well together. I need to manage my workload, so I'll head back to play domestic cricket. I'm still available for Test matches, and I leave for the Hundred in a few days."


Shubman Gill: "It’s been an excellent series. The hunger and determination we showed after the first loss were phenomenal. Many of the players had long flights and were not used to the conditions, but their adaptation was remarkable. I've been to Sri Lanka once for the Asia Cup, and I'm looking forward to going there again and performing well".

TossDetails: Sri Lanka Won The Toss And Elected To Field
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
CompetitionName: India Tour Of Sri Lanka T20 Series 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
India and Sri Lanka are gearing up for a thrilling three-match T20I series starting on July 27, followed by three ODIs.


India, the visitors, enter the contest on the back of a 4-1 series victory over Zimbabwe. However, they will start this series with a new captain and coach, Surya Kumar Yadav and Gautam Gambhir, respectively. With veterans Kohli, Rohit, and Jadeja bidding farewell to the format, the onus now falls on Pant, Hardik, and Surya to lead the charge. These players have a knack for winning matches and will be eager to carry their form forward. Bumrah has been rested for the series to manage his workload.


Sri Lanka, on the other hand, come into the series after a disappointing T20 World Cup. They, too, have undergone changes in coaching and captaincy. Sanath Jayasuriya will serve as their interim coach, while the cool-headed Asalanka, who recently led Jaffna to a title triumph, is set to captain the team. Sri Lanka has added the experienced Chandimal and Perera to their squad for this series and will be looking to start on a positive note.


With both teams featuring new-look squads and the stakes sky-high, which team will emerge on top? Fans are eagerly anticipating a competitive and entertaining series.

Head-To-Head in T20Is:

In as many as 29 games battled between the two teams, India dominated the contest with 19 wins to Sri Lanka's 9 wins while one game ended in no result..


Pitch Report : 

"There's a cool breeze blowing across the ground, which will bring the temperature down. The surface is hard with some visible cracks.
Compared to the LPL surface, this one looks quite different, with more cracks. As the ball loses its hardness, it will tend to stick in the surface. However, it should still be good for batting, and we can expect plenty of runs here."


Toss:-
The Coin has Spun in the Lankan's Favour as they have decided to  first.

Charith Asalanka:- "We've decided to bowl first as the pitch looks promising, and we want to assess its behavior. We're opting for a 6-5 combination of batters and bowlers. Each player has a specific role, which is why we've chosen to go with 5 bowlers. You can look forward to more wins and consistent performances from our team."

Suryakumar Yadav:-"The pitch looks good, so we're fine with batting first. Our brand of cricket remains unchanged. The relationship between me and Gambhir has been special for many years. Dube, Samson, Khaleel, and Washington are the four players missing out today. The World Cup is behind us; we're starting fresh, and this is a new challenge."

India kicked off the series with a commanding 43-run victory over Sri Lanka, taking a 1-0 lead. Put into bat first, India set an imposing total of 213 for 7 in their 20 overs. The opening duo of Gill and Jaiswal got India off to a flying start, punishing the Sri Lankan bowlers with aggressive stroke play. The highlight of the innings was Surya Kumar Yadav's composed half-century, which stabilized the innings. Pant provided a late flourish, ensuring India reached a formidable score. Pathirana was the standout bowler for Sri Lanka, claiming four wickets.

In response, Sri Lanka began their chase with confidence as Pathum Nissanka and Kusal Mendis put together an 84-run opening stand. Mendis fell for a well-made 45, but Nissanka continued to anchor the innings, partnering with Perera to add another 50 runs. However, once Nissanka was dismissed, the Indian bowlers seized control. Sri Lanka's batting lineup crumbled, losing the last nine wickets for just 30 runs, ultimately falling short by 43 runs.

Riyan Parag was instrumental in India's bowling attack, picking up three wickets. Arshdeep Singh and Axar Patel also contributed significantly, each taking two wickets. India's balanced performance with both bat and ball highlighted their dominance, setting the tone for the rest of the series.

Player of the Match:
Suryakumar Yadav (India Skipper): "I believe they played a strong brand of cricket from the very first ball. Despite losing wickets, they maintained a high tempo. We had practiced here for two to three days and were well-prepared for the pitch conditions. Given that we recently won the World Cup, we never doubted our ability to stay in control. Fortunately, there was no dew to contend with"

Charitha Asalanka (Sri Lanka Skipper): "Certainly, we weren't up to the mark with the ball during the powerplay. However, we made a strong comeback, and at one point, it seemed they might reach 240. We could have performed better with the bat. The 6-5 combination is an experiment, but it's the approach we should consider for the future."

India Triumphs Over Sri Lanka in Rain-Shortened Thriller to seal the T20I series ! The Men in Blue showcased their prowess in an 8-over chase, defeating Sri Lanka by 7 wickets and with 9 balls to spare. Sri Lanka batting first, got off to a great start, with Pathum Nissanka's 32 and Kusal Perera's blistering 53 off 34 balls providing a strong foundation, after which Ravi Bishnoi shone with the ball for India claiming 3/26, supported by Axar Patel, Arshdeep Singh and Hardik Pandya, who each took two wickets to pull back the momentum and restrict Sri Lanka to 161/9.

Chasing a revised target of 78 runs in 8 overs, India came out with all guns blazing. Yashasvi Jaiswal set the tone with a rapid 30 off 15 balls, and despite losing Sanju Samson early, captain Suryakumar Yadav’s explosive 26 off 12 and Hardik Pandya’s unbeaten 22 off 9 balls sealed the victory for the Men in Blue.

 

Charith Asalanka, Sri Lanka Captain: "Disappointed with the way we batted at the death. This pitch gets tough to bat on as the ball gets older and as professional cricketers, we must do better. We were behind by 15-20 runs. The weather also played its part, and it's not easy to bowl 8 overs with a wet outfield."

 

Suryakumar Yadav, India Captain: "We spoke about this before the start of the tournament - the brand of cricket we want to play. This is the template we want to move forward with. Considering the weather, anything below 160 would have been nice. The rain helped us and the way the boys batted was wonderful. Very happy for the boys, they showed a lot of character in tough situations."

 

Ravi Bishnoi is the Player of the match

Ravi Bishnoi: "The pitch was a little different from yesterday. It was turning a bit and helping the spinners in the first innings. I stuck to my plans. It's a good responsibility to bowl in the death overs; it means the captain and the management trust me."

India and Sri Lanka are all set to play the final game of their three-match T20I series on July 30, 2024, at the Pallekele International Stadium.


With the series already sealed by India in the first two games, first by 43 runs and the second by seven wickets in a rain-curtailed-game,  they will now look to test their bench strength with different combinations and aim for a clean sweep. The Indian team has been in stupendous form with both bat and ball. Jaiswal's explosive starts and Suryakumar Yadav's versatile batting have been highlights, while Ravi Bishnoi has stood out as the leading bowler, ably supported by Arshdeep Singh and Riyan Parag. This first series under the combination of Gautam Gambhir and Suryakumar Yadav has already been a success, and they will be looking to end the series on a high note.
Sri Lanka, on the other hand, have struggled throughout the series, particularly their middle order, which collapsed significantly—losing nine wickets for 30 runs in the first game and seven wickets for 31 runs in the second game. However, their top order has been impressive, spearheaded by Nissanka's magnificent performances. Kusal Perera and Mendis have also shown good form with the bat. Pathirana has successfully dismissed Suryakumar Yadav in both games, and Hasaranga has taken Jaiswal's wicket in both matches. They will be keen to replicate their performances once again. Sri Lanka will be looking to change their middle-order fortunes and will eye a consolation win to end the series on a positive note.

Head-To-Head in T20Is:
In the 31 games played between the two teams, India has emerged Victorious on 21 occasions while Sri Lanka has managed to win nine games. One game ended with no result.



 

Pitch Report (Russel Arnold):

"A strong wind is blowing across the field, likely to clear away the concerning clouds, but we may still see intermittent showers. We're on a new pitch right next to the one used in the last two games. This surface is drier, with visible cracks, so expect a significant turn. Slower deliveries will be particularly effective here.

There's dew on the ground, making the ball wet and causing it to slide. As a result, chasing might be the preferable option. A target of 160-170 should be competitive. The slower you bowl, the more difficult it will be for batters to play their strokes. The dew will also make it challenging to grip the ball properly."

Toss:- Sri Lanka has won the toss and opted to bowl first.

Charith Asalanka: "We are going to bowl first. The pitch looks dry. There was a batting collapse when the ball got older, making it harder to bat. We've planned a bit differently this time. We have one change in the lineup, Wickramasinghe comes in for Dasun."

Suryakumar Yadav: "We would've liked to chase as well, considering the weather. It becomes difficult for the bowling team to control the ball later. We have four players resting today - Hardik, Axar, Rishabh, and Arshdeep. We talked about the brand of cricket we want to play, and it's about improving every game and being the best version of ourselves."

In a nail-biting encounter at the Pallekele International Cricket Stadium, India edged out Sri Lanka in a super over after the match ended in a tie. Both teams scored 137 in their allotted 20 overs, leading to the dramatic finish.

India, batting first, posted a total of 137/9. Despite early setbacks, Shubman Gill (39 off 37) and Riyan Parag (26 off 18) provided some stability. The standout bowler for Sri Lanka was Maheesh Theekshana, who took 3 wickets for 28 runs. Chamindu Wickramasinghe and Wanindu Hasaranga also contributed significantly, each taking crucial wickets to keep the Indian batting lineup in check.

Sri Lanka's chase saw a solid start from Kusal Mendis (43 off 41) and Kusal Perera (46 off 34), but they struggled to maintain momentum, losing wickets at critical junctures. Ravi Bishnoi and Washington Sundar were the pick of the Indian bowlers, each claiming two wickets to keep the pressure on while Rinku and Surya too contributed with two wickets. The match eventually ended in a tie, with Sri Lanka finishing at 137/8.

In the super over, India's bowlers held their nerve to secure a thrilling victory, sealing the series. This win marked a significant achievement for Suryakumar Yadav's leadership and highlighted the depth and resilience of the Indian team.

Washington Sundar | Player of the Match:
"All the work I've put in, along with blessings from God, really helped me today. I tried to stay calm throughout. I'm very grateful to SKY for trusting me with the ball. It's a wonderful opportunity, and I just focused on doing what I'm supposed to do. We did our homework on their batters, and I aimed to hit the right lengths."

Charith Asalanka: 
"I am really disappointed with our batting lineup, especially the middle-order and lower middle-order. The poor shot selection was a major issue. Hasaranga was sent up the order because the spinners were bowling, and he had the license to hit a few boundaries, but it didn't work out. We made wrong shot selections on this pitch. The target was definitely achievable, and we need to perform better as professional cricketers. I want to see improved batting performances in the ODIs. Our top three and four have done well, which is the only positive for us."

Suryakumar Yadav | Player of the Series:
"More than the last over, I feel the real turning point was when we were 30/4. The boys showed incredible character to reach 140, which was a par score on that track. I told them that if we put our hearts into it, we could pull it off. Their skill level and self-confidence make my job easy. The positivity and care they have for each other are unbelievable. After the last game, I told a few boys they would be rested, and they were ready to sit out without hesitation. They make my job easy, and I feel little pressure when I bat. As I said before the series, I don't want to just be a captain; I want to be a leader."

Dunith Wellalage is Player of the Match

Dunith Wellalage: "I came with a plan knowing the wicket was turning. My goal was to put their bowlers under pressure. Our skipper Wanindu Hasaranga changed the game for us. Overall, we played a wonderful match today."

 

 

Rohit Sharma, India Skipper:  "The score was gettable, but it required good batting to reach it. We batted well in patches but lacked consistent momentum. We had the upper hand, but then we lost a couple of wickets. The partnership between KL and Axar brought us back into the game. It was a bit disappointing at the end, but these things happen. Sri Lanka played well, and in the end, it was a fair result. The pitch remained the same; it wasn't one where you could just come in and play your shots—you had to dig in. The game swung back and forth between both teams. We should have managed to get that one run."

 

 

 

Charith Asalanka, Sri Lanka Skipper: "I did believe we could defend the total; we should have done a bit better to restrict them. The pitch turned more in the afternoon, but under lights, batting became easier. When the left-hander came in, I felt I could bowl as it was spinning a lot. I'm happy with the energy we showed in the field. Dunith's knock was crucial, and Nissanka batted well."

The venue remains unchanged, but the hosts will be missing their star player, Wanindu Hasaranga, due to a hamstring injury from the previous game. The Indian team, which dominated much of the first match, aims to rectify their past errors. Meanwhile, the spirited Sri Lankan side seeks to maintain the momentum they gained in the latter stages of the first ODI. 

 

 

PITCH REPORT: 
Russell Arnold: "It's a scorching afternoon, and the warm breeze adds to the heat. We've shifted a few strips over, and the pitch looks dry, much like the one from a couple of days ago. The cracks on the surface are quite wide, indicating significant crumbling as the game progresses. The captain who wins the toss will likely choose to bat first. Batters will need to focus on finding the gaps and running hard to wear down the opposition."

 

 

TOSS:
Sri Lanka has won the toss and has elected to first

 

 

Charith Asalanka, Sri Lanka Skipper: "Definitely we are batting first. The pitch appears similar to the previous match with minimal changes. Our strategy remains unchanged from the last game. Wanindu Hasaranga and Mohamed Shiraz are out, replaced by Kamindu Mendis and Jeffrey Vandersay. The previous game gave us a boost, and now we need to capitalize on that and secure a win."

 

 

Rohit Sharma, India Skipper:  "We understand what's required when chasing, so we've talked to the team about it. You can't always approach the game with the same mindset; you need to adjust to the conditions at hand. We've emphasized this to the boys. It's crucial to adapt quickly and play with freedom. Staying focused on the present and what needs to be done today is important. We're going with the same XI. As for the tie, it wasn't a blow to morale. Analyzing the game, both teams dominated at different stages, making it a fair outcome in the end."

Sri Lanka defeated India by 32 runs. Batting first, Sri Lanka scored 240-9, with notable contributions from Avishka Fernando (40), Dunith Wellalage (39), and Kamindu Mendis (40). Washington Sundar and Kuldeep Yadav were the pick of the bowlers for India. In reply, India managed 208 in 42.2 overs, led by Rohit Sharma's 64 and Axar Patel's 44. Jeffrey Vandersay starred with the ball for Sri Lanka, taking 6 wickets for 36 runs, while Charith Asalanka chipped in with 3 wickets.

 

 

Jeffrey Vandersay is Player of the Match 

Jeffrey Vandersay: "There was a lot of pressure coming into the side, especially after a layoff. While it's easy to take credit for my performance, I want to acknowledge the batters who scored 240 runs, making it easier for me to bowl in good areas. With Hasaranga, our No. 1 spinner, out, I had to adapt to the team's atmosphere and balance quickly. I need to keep pushing myself to perform well."

 

Rohit Sharma, India Skipper:  "Losing a game is always painful; it's not just about those 10 overs. Consistency is key, and we didn't manage that today. While it's disappointing, these things happen. We need to adapt to the conditions in front of us. With a left-right combination, we thought it would be easier to rotate the strike—credit to Jeffrey Vandersay for his impressive six-wicket haul.  Don't want to look too much into how we played. But there'll be talks about our batting in the middle overs"

 

Charith Asalanka, Sri Lanka Skipper: "I was quite satisfied with our score of 240, which I felt was sufficient. As a captain, having an abundance of spin options is a good problem to have. Vandersay delivered an unbelievable spell, especially considering the opposition was over 90 runs when he started bowling. My primary role is as a batter, so I focus on scoring runs first, and then I can contribute with my bowling."

Rohit Sharma, India Skipper: "Plenty to play for, and we've been challenged in the last two matches. It's clear what we need to do with both the bat and the ball. We've addressed it as a group. Sri Lanka clinched a convincing victory by 110 runs. In their innings, they posted 248-7 in 50 overs. Key contributions came from Avishka Fernando, who scored a solid 96 off 102 balls, and Kusal Mendis, who added 59 off 82. Riyan Parag was the standout bowler for India, taking 3 wickets for 54 runs.

In reply, India's batting lineup crumbled, managing only 138 runs in 26.1 overs. Rohit Sharma top-scored with a quick 35 off 20 balls, but the rest of the batting order struggled against the Sri Lankan bowlers. Dunith Wellalage was particularly effective, claiming 5 wickets for just 27 runs, leading Sri Lanka to a dominant win. Sri Lanka win the series 2 to NIL and win a bilateral series against India after 27 years. 

 

 

Avishka Fernando is the Player of the Match 

Avishka Fernando: "I'm very happy with the innings. The batters came together and did a good job. It was a challenging wicket, and while I'm a bit disappointed not to get a hundred, I'm thrilled with the win."

 

 

Dunith Wellalage is Player of the Series 

Dunith Wellalage: "I want to thank my skipper, teammates, and coaching staff. Everyone gave me great support, and that's why I'm here. We adjusted well to the wicket as it was turning, similar to the first two ODIs, and committed fewer mistakes today. The batters did a great job, and then the spinners bowled exceptionally well. Everyone is supporting each other, and I am excited to be part of this team."

 

 

Rohit Sharma, India Skipper: "I don't think it's a major concern, but it's something we need to address individually and within our game plan. It's a joke to think that playing for India allows any room for complacency. When I am captain, complacency is not an option. However, you have to give credit where it's due—Sri Lanka played better than us today. We assessed the conditions and chose our combinations accordingly. Some players needed to be considered, hence the changes. We have many areas that need improvement, rather than just focusing on the positives."

 

 

Charith Asalanka, Sri Lanka Skipper: " I am a happy captain right now. The team did everything right throughout the series. We all knew India had a strong batting lineup, so we focused on our strength, which is spin, and we backed it fully. The team is in high spirits, and our coach, Sanath Jayasuriya, has been very active and supportive. The boys have really enjoyed the team environment."

PreMatchCommentary:
The Indian cricket team is gearing up for an intense and exciting three-month Test season, beginning with a two-match series against Bangladesh, starting on September 19, 2024, at the iconic MA Chidambaram Stadium in Chennai. This season promises to be a grueling one for India, as they will play a total of 10 Test matches—five at home and five away. After facing Bangladesh, India will take on New Zealand in another home series, followed by a crucial five-match series against Australia down under in November and December.
 

Bangladesh enters this contest with immense confidence, having just completed a historic series win against Pakistan on their home soil. This victory marks Bangladesh's third away Test series triumph, and it has come at a crucial time when they are still in contention for a spot in the World Test Championship (WTC) final.


The standout performers for Bangladesh in the Pakistan series were Litton Das and Mehidy Hasan Miraz, both of whom played pivotal roles while Mushfiqur Rahim's 191 in the first Tests was their key to victory. In a thrilling comeback during the second Test, Bangladesh was reduced to 26/6 in their first innings, trailing by more than 200 runs. However, Litton and Mehidy stitched together a record-breaking seventh-wicket partnership that turned the game around, ultimately leading Bangladesh to a convincing six-wicket victory.

Mehidy Hasan’s heroics were not limited to his batting. With the ball, he claimed 10 wickets across the two games, making him the leading wicket-taker in the series for Bangladesh. He was closely followed by Hasan Mahmud, who took 8 wickets, and the young pace sensation Nahid Rana, who grabbed 6 wickets. Bangladesh’s bowling attack, spearheaded by these players, will aim to carry this winning momentum into the series against India, with the WTC final spot still very much within reach.
 

India, on the other hand, returns to the international arena after a considerable break. The last time they played was in early August, and they will be keen to get back into the groove with a fresh start. India currently sits at the top of the WTC points table with 68.52 PCT in nine matches so far and has the most remaining matches (10) to play. With the stakes high, they are aiming to consolidate their position and make a strong case for the WTC final yet again.


The pitch at the MA Chidambaram Stadium, known for assisting spinners, will likely see India fielding a spin-heavy attack. The combination of local hero Ravichandran Ashwin and Ravindra Jadeja will form the crux of India’s bowling attack, supported by a third spinner. India may also go with two pacers to maintain a balanced lineup, with the possibility of including one of their young fast-bowling talents. The Chepauk wicket, traditionally known for its turn and variable bounce, will test both teams’ batting skills against high-quality spin.


India’s squad is a blend of experience and youth, and the team management will likely rely on their seasoned players to lead the charge. With senior players such as Ashwin and Jadeja handling the spin department, and experienced batters like Virat Kohli and Rohit Sharma in the middle, India will look to dominate Bangladesh from the outset.
 

A Battle with High Stakes

With both teams eyeing the WTC final, this series promises to be a fascinating contest. Bangladesh is riding high on their recent success and will be hungry to challenge the top-ranked side. For India, this is the beginning of a crucial season, and they will aim to start it on a high note, especially with a challenging tour of Australia looming later in the year.

Head-To-Head in Tests:

In the 13 games contested between the two teams, India have clearly dominated the contest with 11 wins while other two games has been ended in a draw. Bangladesh are yet to open their win account against India so far.



Stats At MA Chidambaram Stadium.

In the 34 matches played at this venue, teams batting first have won 12 times, while teams batting second have emerged victorious on 10 occasions. Eleven matches have ended in a draw, and one game resulted in a tie. Spinners have dominated at Chepauk, taking 584 wickets, while pacers have managed 381 wickets. Interestingly, only two Indian batters have scored triple centuries in Tests, and both of these remarkable feats were achieved at this ground. Notably, Virender Sehwag also has another triple century to his name, which he scored in Multan.

This surface, reminiscent of the ones that saw Bedi and Prasanna weave their magic, hints at bounce and turn. As the match unfolds, expect the spinners to dominate proceedings increasingly.

However, residual moisture lurks beneath, offering early promise for the quicks. It brings to mind Kapil Dev's exploits here in the '80s.

The toss winner faces a crucial decision: exploit early conditions or bank on later deterioration. This evolving pitch could shift the balance between bat and ball, making for a compelling Test match narrative.

In a remarkable turn of events, India secured a convincing 7-wicket victory over Bangladesh in the second Test at Green Park, Kanpur, completing a 2-0 series sweep. The win, achieved with more than a session to spare, seemed improbable after nearly three days were lost to rain and wet outfield conditions.

The match began with India winning the toss and electing to field, a rare choice for the team in home Tests. Bangladesh's first innings, interrupted by weather delays, saw Mominul Haque as the standout performer with an unbeaten century. However, his efforts were not enough to prevent the visitors from being dismissed for 233, with Jasprit Bumrah leading India's bowling attack.

India's response was nothing short of extraordinary. The hosts adopted an aggressive T20-style approach in their first innings, breaking records for the fastest team totals at various stages. Rohit Sharma set the tone with three sixes as his first scoring shots, while Yashasvi Jaiswal and KL Rahul contributed quick half-centuries. India declared at 285/9 in just 34.4 overs, establishing a 52-run lead.

Bangladesh's second innings crumbled under pressure from India's formidable bowling lineup. Despite resistance from Shadman Islam and Mushfiqur Rahim, the visitors were bundled out for 146. Ravindra Jadeja, Jasprit Bumrah, and Ravichandran Ashwin shared the spoils, each claiming three wickets.

Chasing a modest target of 95, India lost early wickets but remained in control. Yashasvi Jaiswal once again showcased his aggressive intent, scoring a brisk 51 off 45 balls. Fittingly, Rishabh Pant hit the winning boundary, sealing India's victory.

This win solidifies India's position at the top of the World Test Championship standings and marks a successful start to Gautam Gambhir's tenure as coach. The team's ability to force a result in such time-constrained circumstances highlights their dominance in home conditions and their commitment to pursuing victory against all odds.

The match will be remembered for India's bold strategy and execution, turning what could have been a dull draw into a thrilling contest. 

 

Yashasvi Jaiswal (Player of the Match):
"I was just focused on what I could do for the team. The conditions in Chennai and here were different, so I adapted accordingly and gave my best. Every innings is important, and I always prepare with that mindset. Rohit bhai and Gautam sir told me to bat freely, and that’s exactly what we aimed for—to win and play with intent."

Najmul Hossain Shanto (Bangladesh Captain):
"We took early wickets but couldn’t capitalize later. In both matches, we didn't bat well according to the conditions. Our batters got starts but didn’t convert. Mominul's innings and Miraz’s bowling were positives, and I hope Miraz can continue this form in future matches."

Rohit Sharma (India Captain):
"In life, we all move on. Rahul Bhai did a great job, and now we’re working with Gambhir, who has a clear mindset. It’s early, but we’ve started well. Losing a couple of days meant we had to keep the game moving. After getting them out for 233, it wasn’t about runs but how many overs we could bowl at them. The pitch didn’t offer much, but the bowlers made it happen.We took a calculated risk by batting aggressively, even knowing we might get bowled out quickly. Akash Deep has the fitness and energy to bowl long spells, and it's important to have players ready when needed."

In a stunning display of batting prowess, India dominated Bangladesh with a massive 297/6 in their 20 overs, securing a 133-run victory in this T20 match.

Sanju Samson's remarkable 111 off just 47 balls electrified the stadium. With eleven fours and eight sixes, the wicketkeeper-batsman showcased his exceptional form, with a strike rate of 236.17. Not to be outdone, Captain Suryakumar Yadav's 75 off 35 balls demonstrated his T20 batting mastery, solidifying his reputation as one of the most formidable batsmen in this format.

Riyan Parag (34 off 13) and Hardik Pandya (47 off 18) then unleashed a fierce onslaught in the final overs, pummeling the boundary rope. Bangladesh's bowler Tanzim Hasan Sakib picked up three wickets but conceded 66 runs in 4 overs, leaving their entire bowling unit reeling from India's relentless attack.

Bangladesh's response fell short, with Parvez Hossain Emon dismissed for a golden duck, setting the tone for their innings. Despite Towhid Hridoy's resilient 63* and Litton Das's brisk 42, they never seemed to be in contention. Ravi Bishnoi was India's standout bowler, claiming 3 wickets for 30 runs in 4 overs, choking the Bangladesh middle order. Mayank Yadav's pace proved too much to handle, and Varun Chakravarthy's economical 4-0-23-0 maintained the pressure throughout.

In the end, Bangladesh's 164/7 was insufficient. India's dominant performance highlighted their strength in both batting and bowling. While questions may arise about Bangladesh's strategy, for now, India can revel in their well-deserved victory and the confidence it brings. 

 

Najmul Hossain Shanto | Bangladesh Captain:

The leadership has shown immense faith in me, not just with words but through their actions as well."  
 

Hardik Pandya | Player Of The Series :
"The freedom the skipper and coach have given us is really benefiting everyone in the team. It’s allowing us to bring out the best in each other. When you enjoy each other’s success, it creates a hunger to do even more. Physically, I’m feeling good, and I’m grateful for that. That shot over covers, off the back foot, was just a chip that cleared the ropes—one of my favourites because it’s not something you pull off every day." 
 

Suryakumar Yadav | India Captain:
"I think we've achieved a lot as a team. I had mentioned that we wanted to build a team of selfless cricketers, and we’re seeing that happen, with everyone enjoying each other’s performances. The camaraderie is really showing. As Gauti bhai said before the series, no one is bigger than the team—whether you're on 49 or 99, you still have to go for the big shot. That's exactly what Sanju did today.We need to stay flexible with both batting and bowling, and it’s great to see bowlers stepping up when needed and batters being adaptable. Their performances were commendable. In terms of improvement, we just need to keep up the good habits on the field and remain consistent."

TossDetails: India Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
CompetitionName: New Zealand Tour Of India Test Series 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
The Men in Blue are set to return to Test cricket with a three-match series against New Zealand, kicking off at the M. Chinnaswamy Stadium in Bengaluru. Fresh off a dominant victory over Bangladesh in both T20Is and Tests, India are brimming with confidence as they inch closer to securing a spot in the World Test Championship (WTC) final. With a near-unchanged lineup, the home side is looking to continue their impressive form on familiar turf.

India has a clear advantage. Their squad, led by Rohit Sharma, Virat Kohli and the lethal spin duo of Ravichandran Ashwin and Ravindra Jadeja, is a force to be reckoned with—especially at home. The return of pace ace Jasprit Bumrah adds even more firepower to India’s bowling attack. With only three more wins needed from their remaining eight Tests to secure a WTC final berth, the hosts are in a strong position.

For New Zealand, the absence of Kane Williamson leaves a significant gap in their batting lineup. However, the Kiwis will need more than individual heroics to challenge India’s depth and form.

Weather could play a role, with rain expected in Bengaluru. If the pitch becomes seamer-friendly, New Zealand might find some respite by putting India into bat under cloudy skies. But even wet conditions are unlikely to shake India’s confidence, given their well-rounded squad.

Head-To-Head In Tests:

In 62 Test matches between India and New Zealand, India has claimed victory 22 times, while New Zealand has won 13 matches. The remaining 27 games ended in draws. On Indian soil, the two teams have clashed in 36 Tests, with India winning 17 and New Zealand managing only 2 wins. Notably, the Kiwis' last victory in India dates back to 1988, highlighting India's dominance at home over the past few decades.

 

Did You Know?

The Last Time NZ defeated India in Tests in India, Ajaz Patel was less than 40 days old, and other New Zealand players from the current squad were not born!
New Zealand have never defeated India in Bengaluru in their six attempts so far! 


8:57 AM IST: The Toss has been Delayed due to Rain

11:00 AM IST: It's Still Drizzling at Bengaluru and the wait continues!

11:30 AM IST: That Will be Lunch On Day 1!

2:00 PM IST: And... unfortunately, the covers are back on as the drizzles have returned. It looks like we'll have to wait a bit longer.

2:10 PM IST: The Second Session is also washed out fully and it will be Tea on day 1! 

2:30 PM IST : Play on Day 1 Has been Called off  



Day 2  |  8:15 AM IST: The Weather seems fine, We will have the Toss at 8:45 AM and Play will begin at 9:15 AM IST



 


Toss- India won the toss and elected to bat first! 



Rohit Sharma | India Captain:
We’re going to bat first. The pitch has been under covers and might be a bit sticky early, but it’s important to put runs on the board. We’ve been playing well in recent Tests. This is a fresh series, and we want to start strong. Two changes from the last Test—Gill misses out, Sarfaraz comes in. Kuldeep replaces Akash.
 

Tom Latham | New Zealand:
The wicket's been under covers, so hopefully we can use that to our advantage early with the ball. There's been some weather around, so our prep hasn’t been ideal. We’re going with three seamers alongside Ajaz Patel, and we have two all-rounders who can bowl spin as well.
PostMatchCommentary:
Day 1- Washed Out

Day 2, 
IND:- 46/10 (1.46 rpo, 4x4,0x6) || NZ- 180/3 (3.6 rpo, 22x4, 3x6)

NZ- 110/2 (4.44 rpo, 16x4, 1x6)   
 

New Zealand defeated India by 8 wickets in the first test of a three-match series, marking their first test victory in India in 36 years. India, choosing to bat first, was dismissed for a record-low home score of 46 runs. Matt Henry led the bowling attack with figures of 5/15.New Zealand responded with 402, featuring Rachin Ravindra's maiden test century (134) and Devon Conway's 91. Tim Southee contributed a quick 65.India's second innings saw a remarkable turnaround, scoring 462. Sarfaraz Khan (150) and Rishabh Pant (99) formed a crucial 177-run partnership. However, India collapsed, losing their last 7 wickets for just 54 runs.Chasing 107, New Zealand reached the target comfortably, with Will Young (48*) and Rachin Ravindra (39*) guiding them home despite early wickets from Jasprit Bumrah (2/29).The win gives New Zealand a 1-0 lead in the series 

 

Rohit Sharma | India Captain:
"We batted well in the second innings, especially after struggling in the first. A couple of guys stood up when needed, and that put us back in the game. Being 350 runs behind, we had to focus on playing each ball and building partnerships. It was a great effort not to fold under pressure.
 Both (Sarfaraz and Pant)  are batting heroes. Rishabh takes risks, but they pay off—it was a mature innings from him. Sarfaraz, in just his fourth Test, showed great maturity too. When you're clear-headed, things fall into place.
I knew overcast conditions would be tough, but I didn’t expect us to be bowled out for under 50. Full credit to New Zealand for bowling brilliantly. These things happen, but we’ll take the positives and move forward. We’ve bounced back before, like we did against England, and we’re ready for the next game." 
 

Tom Latham | New Zealand Captain:
"We were considering batting first too, so it was a good toss to lose. The bowlers hit the right areas and bowled India out cheaply, which set things up for us. We knew India would come hard in the second innings, but we bowled well with the second new ball to finish the job. Honestly, I never expected that. The bowlers did a great job, and the conditions helped us, but full credit to the team. Rachin and Southee’s partnership with the bat was also crucial for building a solid lead He’s been fantastic, troubling us in the nets with his extra bounce and pace. Having Tim Southee’s experience alongside him was brilliant. Rachin was outstanding with the bat, setting the tone beautifully. He’s shown his class over the last year, and we’re lucky to have him on our side. 
 

Rachin Ravindra | Player of the Match:
"It’s a nice city and a good wicket to bat on. It’s about having clarity in what needs to be done, and preparation helps. I’ve worked on playing on different surfaces—red soil, black soil, and against various types of bowlers. I was fortunate to get those facilities in Chennai. I wouldn’t say I’m looking to attack, but I focus on scoring when possible. The support has been amazing, and it’s great to have family backing me, I enjoyed my time coming out here and playing"

TossDetails: New Zealand Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
CompetitionName: New Zealand Tour Of India Test Series 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
India returns to the Maharashtra Cricket Association Stadium in Pune for the second Test against New Zealand, eager to bounce back after a rare home defeat. The pitch, with lower bounce and more turn, plays perfectly into India’s strengths, offering an ideal platform for their world-class spinners.Rohit Sharma’s team has made a key addition with Washington Sundar, who adds depth to the attack. Meanwhile, Rishabh Pant, after his outstanding partnership with Sarfaraz Khan in Bengaluru, is fully fit and ready for action.India’s shock first-innings collapse in the opening Test, where they were bowled out for 46, was followed by a spirited fightback, but New Zealand’s disciplined bowling, led by Tim Southee, sealed the win.All eyes are on Rohit's men to demonstrate the cricket that has made them a powerhouse in home conditions. With their wealth of talent, strategic depth, and home advantage, Team India stands ready to produce another memorable performance in their history.

Pitch Report: 
The surface composition is consistent—black soil characteristics are seen at both venues, Bangalore and Pune. Looking at the crucial good length zone, we're seeing significantly less moisture and minimal grass cover. With these conditions, batting first would be the optimal choice for whoever wins the toss, and spinners should find assistance right from the start. 






Toss:- New Zealand won the toss and elected to bat first.



Tom Latham:
We've chosen to bat first today. The wicket looks somewhat changed from our previous game - much less grass coverage out there. We're anticipating the ball to turn, which is typical when playing in this region. It's been a tremendously special achievement for our squad, and while we took time to enjoy that milestone, we're now completely focused on our game here in Pune. Matt Henry misses due to niggle while Santner replaces him in the squad.


Rohit Sharma:
We Would have preferred to bat first as well. That first Test was challenging - the opening session didn't work in our favor, but our second innings batting showed real character. There are positive takeaways from that match which we'll look to build on here. It's crucial to find momentum when you're on the back foot in Test cricket, and that's exactly what we managed. The surface is looking quite dry. We recognize the critical importance of those initial 10 overs. We're making three changes to our lineup - we'll be without Siraj, KL and Kuldeep today. Akash Deep, Washington and Gill will take their places.
PostMatchCommentary:
Day 1:- 
NZ - 259/10 ( 3.27rpo, 25x4, 3x6) || IND 16/1 ( 1.45rpo, 4x4, 0x6)
 

Day 2:-  
IND - 140/6 ( 4.95 rpo, 10x4 , 5x6) || NZ - 198/5 ( 3.73 rpo, 20x4, 1x6) 

Day 3:-  
NZ - 57/5 ( 3.42rpo, 4x4, 1x6) || IND 245/10 ( 4.60rpo, 24x4, 4x6) 

 

New Zealand etched their name in the history books with their first-ever series win in India, clinching the second Test by 113 runs. Winning the toss and opting to bat first, New Zealand put up a competitive total of 259 runs, thanks to crucial half-centuries from Rachin Ravindra and Devon Conway. India's spinners dominated, with Washington Sundar claiming seven wickets and R Ashwin taking three.

In response, the Indian batting lineup struggled against New Zealand’s spinners, particularly Mitchell Santner, who delivered a masterclass by taking seven wickets. India was bowled out for a mere 156, with Yashasvi Jaiswal and Shubman Gill both scoring 30. Trailing by 103 runs, New Zealand built on their lead, scoring 255 in their second innings. Tom Latham led the charge with a resilient 86, setting India a challenging target of 359 runs. Sundar continued his good form with four wickets.

Chasing 359, India was dismissed for 245. Santner once again proved to be India’s nemesis, picking up another five-wicket haul. Despite Jaiswal’s fighting knock of 77, India fell short. With this victory, New Zealand sealed the series 2-0, with one match remaining.


Rohit | India captain: 
Disappointing. It's not what we expected. Got to give credit to NZ - they played better than us. We failed to capitalise on certain moments. We failed to respond to those challenges. And we sit here today. Didn't think we batted well enough to get runs on the board. You've got to pick 20 wickets to win, yes, but batters have to put runs on the board. Was a great fightback to restrict them to 250-odd but we knew it was going to be challenging. When they started off, they were 200/3 and for us to come back and get them bowled out for 259 was a great effort. Wasn't a pitch where a lot was happening. We just didn't bat well enough. Things would've been slightly different had we got a bit closer in the first innings. We want to show up well at Wankhede and try and win that Test. It's a collective failure. I'm not somebody who would blame just the batters or the bowlers. We will come out with better intent, better ideas and better methods at Wankhede.

Latham | NZ captain: 
Really special feeling. Proud to be in this position. Whole team effort and a clear example of everyone pitching in. When you come over here you want to put your best foot forward. Putting runs on the board at the start was really important. Have to mention Mitch Santner. He was fantastic. Has been around the group a long time, and to finally get a break and bowl the way he has - credit to him. It was about trying to stick to our basics and play the long game. Both surfaces have been different, we've needed to adapt and we've done that very well. The method we played with last night - to put ourselves on the front foot - was terrifc. The way GP played this morning was really important. We knew India were going to come out hot. Didn't realise they were going to come that hot, but we managed to get the breakthroughs in the middle session. Those last two wickets took an age but when Tim took that catch we were really happy.


Santner | Player of the Match:
My approach stayed pretty consistent (in second innings). The conditions were a bit more challenging this time around. Have to acknowledge India's aggressive intent - it was probably the best way to play on that surface. We just maintained our discipline throughout. My body's feeling it now, especially the side after that extended spell of 20-plus overs. But in those moments, you just want to keep pushing through. Each wicket gave me a boost of energy. Really satisfied to have played my part in the team's success. Securing a series win here in India is something special - it's such a tough achievement. Taking wickets definitely helps build your confidence. As spinners, our focus is always on consistency - hitting those same spots repeatedly while mixing up the pace subtly - that's the foundation of our bowling unit's approach.

TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
CompetitionName: New Zealand Tour Of India Test Series 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
India heads into the third Test at Wankhede determined to restore pride and protect their position in the World Test Championship standings. Facing an uncharacteristic 2-0 deficit at home, the team will look to rally under captain Rohit Sharma to end the series on a high. Despite setbacks in Bengaluru and Pune, India has shown resilience and will aim to bring that intensity to Mumbai.

New Zealand’s success has been a testament to their preparation and persistence, with bowlers like Mitchell Santner and Ajaz Patel rising to the occasion. However, India’s own spinners are primed for the Wankhede pitch, known for its bounce and turn, which could tilt conditions in the hosts’ favor.

India’s top order will be eager to set a strong foundation and put pressure on New Zealand, while the bowlers look to apply a decisive impact. Though the series may be out of reach, the team remains focused on delivering a performance that upholds their high standards and ensures vital WTC points. Expect an intense contest as India seeks to close out the series with renewed determination.

Toss:- New Zealand won the toss and elected to bat first. 

 

 

Tom Latham | New Zealand Captain: "We will bat first. It looks a good surface. Hopefully, we can put some runs on the board. Focusing on this Test. We did well in Bengaluru and Pune. But now the focus is on this one. Test Cricket is a funny game. We did not play badly against Sri Lanka. We have tried to keep things simple and play our brand of cricket. Whether you are batting first or bowling first, you have to play well. Sodhi and Henry come in for Southee and Santner"

Rohit Sharma | India Captain: "We would have batted as well. Yeah absolutely, we understand we haven't played well. But again gives us another opportunity to come back and looks a good wicket. Hopefully, we can restrict them to as low as possible and then do well with the bat. Right now our focus is on this Test match. On the back of the mind you need to keep in mind about that (WTC), but right now we need to play our best cricket which we haven't this series. Unfortunately, Bumrah is not well and Siraj comes in place of him."
PostMatchCommentary:
Day 1
NZ:- 235(3.58 rpo, 13x4, 6x6) ll IND - 86/4 (4.52 rpo, 10x4, 1x6) 

Day 2
IND - 177/6 (4.35 rpo, 18x4, 4x6) ll NZ -  171/9 (3.93 rpo, 9x4, 7x6)

Day 3
NZ:- 3/1 (1.28 rpo, 0x4, 0x6) ll IND - 121 (4.15 rpo, 11x4, 1x6)  

New Zealand script unprecedented chapter in Test cricket - first-ever 3-0 whitewash of India at home, ending the hosts' 24-year streak without a series sweep. Chasing 147 to get the vital WTC points, India's resistance crumbled at 121, despite Pant's counter-attacking 64.
The match pivoted on crucial phases: New Zealand's resilient 235 after winning a vital toss, India's response earning a slim 28-run lead. Visitors' adventurous 174 in the second innings, perfectly gauging the deteriorating surface, set up the finale.
From 29/5, it became the Pant show - counter-attacking fifty at a strike rate above 100 keeping Indian hopes alive. Phillips' double-strike and Ajaz's final flourish sealed an unprecedented 3-0 whitewash, India's first at home.The stark scoreline (India 0 - New Zealand 3) marks only the second home series whitewash since South Africa's 2-0 in 1999-2000. A result sending shockwaves through World Test Championship calculations, with India's final hopes now precariously placed. 


 Rohit Sharma | India Captain: 
"Losing a series or losing a Test match is never easy. It is something that is not digestible. We didn't play good cricket. New Zealand played better than us. Credit to them. We have to accept that we didn't play the best cricket and made a lot of mistakes. We didn't score enough first innings score in the previous two matches and were always behind in the game. In this game, we had the lead; we were a little ahead, but we failed to capitalize. While chasing a target, we need to have runs on the board. I had that in mind. It didn't come off. And when it doesn't come off, it looks bad. We come up with a certain mindset while batting; if it comes off, it is great, or else it looks really bad. I had specific strategies that didn't work this series. Our cricket wasn't up to par in these conditions, and we're facing those consequences. As I mentioned, our performance wasn't at its best, and that's why we're in this position. Pant, Gill, and Washington demonstrated how to bat on these surfaces - you need to be proactive. We've been playing on similar pitches for three years now. Unfortunately, our tactical approaches didn't succeed this series. I take responsibility for not delivering my best, both as captain and batsman. As a team unit, we fell short."  


Ajaz Patel | Player of the Match:
"Spin bowling is fundamentally about finding your rhythm. When conditions are favorable, you need to seize the opportunity completely. I was feeling confident during the morning session too. After lunch, there was significantly more turn which worked in my favor. My approach was to keep things uncomplicated and try to outthink the batsmen. Regarding the contest with Pant - he's an exceptional batsman who put us under considerable pressure. It required creative thinking and alternative strategies to deal with him." 


Will Young | Player of the Series: 
"Firstly, for the team to come here and win the series, it is huge. To win one game here is so huge, but to come out again and again and win the series with a 3-0 margin is unbelievable. Really proud of the boys. My batting approach was about simplicity. I focus on maintaining a clear mindset and trusting my defensive technique. It's also important to identify scoring opportunities. Like ducks sitting on water, staying calm. We really enjoyed playing together as a team. About taking Kane's number 3 position? Well, let's see what happens in the next series."
 


Tom Latham | New Zealand Captain: 
"Yeah, I'm absolutely ecstatic. Looking back at the series start, the team has performed exceptionally. To achieve this in Mumbai, on a challenging surface for both batting and bowling, is incredibly satisfying. Our success came from adapting to each venue's conditions. In Bengaluru, we had different players stepping up at crucial moments. Last week it was Mitch's performance, and this time Ajaz, who particularly enjoys bowling here in Mumbai. Our approach was about keeping things uncomplicated. This is exactly what we discussed weeks ago - being proactive and understanding India's style while adapting our game accordingly. The team executed well, and I'm proud to be standing here with this result. We believed our runs were sufficient in these conditions. On this wicket, we knew it would be challenging. Each victory is special - the women's World Cup triumph is fantastic, our win here is remarkable, and the Black Caps' rugby success last night makes it a brilliant time for New Zealand sports."
