TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
CompetitionName: India Tour Of South Africa T20 Series 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
India and South Africa are set for a thrilling four-match T20I series, beginning November 8 at Kingsmead Stadium, Durban. With India riding high as T20 World Champions, thanks to their recent win over South Africa in the finals, the Proteas are keen for redemption on home soil.

Led by the explosive Suryakumar Yadav, India comes in with a six-match winning streak. Despite missing some senior players, they bring young stars like Abhishek Sharma and Rinku Singh, adding depth to their power-packed lineup. South Africa, led by Aiden Markram, fields an almost full-strength squad featuring David Miller and Heinrich Klaasen, making them formidable in familiar conditions.

This series promises exciting matchups: Suryakumar’s strokeplay against South Africa’s pace attack and Miller’s finishing prowess against India’s spinners. With matches across iconic venues in Durban, Gqeberha, Centurion, and Johannesburg, fans can expect a fiercely competitive series as India looks to extend its T20 dominance, while South Africa aims to protect its home pride in what’s sure to be an intense battle.

Head-To-Head in T20Is:
In the 27 games battled between the two teams, India edge over South Africa by 15-11 and one game ended in no-result.

Pitch Report By Shaun Pollock:

An overcast, blustery evening sets the stage for a gripping contest here at Kingsmead. Veteran all-rounder Shaun Pollock notes the hard, true surface is primed to offer pace, bounce and carry - a tantalizing prospect for the quicks with the new ball.

However, the capricious Durban breeze could prove a double-edged sword, potentially aiding the seamers early on, but also allowing the batters to play their strokes confidently. The captain winning the toss faces a crucial decision - capitalize on helpful bowling conditions, or post a challenging first-innings total before the forecast rain arrives later?


Toss:- South Africa have won the toss and decided to bowl first.


Aiden Markram: We will bowl first today. The pitch looks quite good, and since there's been some rain this week, we’re hoping to use any moisture that may still be there to our advantage. It’s also a fantastic chance for the new guys to debut on home turf, and we want them to enjoy every moment of it. We’re a very competitive side, and our discussions have been centered on how we can drive towards positive results

Suryakumar Yadav: We were hoping to bat first. The pitch looks good—much better than the practice one—so our goal is to put up a solid total. The team has made my role easier; everyone plays with a fearless mindset, just like they do for their franchises, and they’ve brought that same energy here.
PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (1-6 Overs) -
India : 56/1 (9.33 rpo, 6x4, 4x6) || South Africa - 49/3 (8.16 rpo, 6x4, 2x6) 

Middle overs (7-15 Overs) -
India : 111/2 (12.33 rpo, 7x4, 8x6) || South Africa - 65/5 (7.22 rpo, 3x4, 5x6) 

Death overs (16-20 Overs) -
India : 35/5 ( 7 rpo, 4x4, 1x6) || South Africa - 27/2 (9.52 rpo, 1x4, 2x6) 
 

India took a 1-0 lead in the series with a commanding 61-run victory. After being put in to bat, India set a formidable target, reaching 202/8, thanks largely to an impressive century from Sanju Samson. He found solid support from Tilak Varma and Suryakumar Yadav, who chipped in with valuable contributions to keep the momentum going. South Africa's Gerald Coetzee was their standout bowler, claiming 3 wickets.

In pursuit of 203, South Africa struggled from the start and fell short by 61 runs, never really managing to get into the chase. India's bowlers dominated the innings, with Varun and Ravi Bishnoi sharing six wickets equally, each taking three crucial scalps. Heinrich Klaasen managed to top-score for South Africa with 25 runs, but it wasn’t enough to steady their innings. The South African batting lineup crumbled, eventually getting bowled out for 141.

Sanju Samson (Player Of The Match)
I’m really enjoying my time out there in the middle. I’ve been in good form, so I’m making the most of it while it lasts. It all comes down to intent—we’ve been focused on playing aggressively and keeping the team on the front foot. You have to aim for those boundary shots; sometimes they work, sometimes they don’t. This was an important win because South Africa is a strong team, especially at home. We’re thrilled to kick off the series in this way.

Aiden Markram ( South Africa Captain)
The toss didn’t play a huge role today. The new ball had a bit of bounce and movement off the surface, which made things tricky early on. From our perspective, it really came down to our batting—we could have done better in that area.

Suryakumar Yadav (India Captain)
Oh really, I didn’t know that! It’s great, though, that we’ve been sticking to our usual style of play. We haven’t changed much, so I’m pleased with the win. Sanju’s hard work is paying off now—he even kept going for big shots in the 90s, always putting the team first. It’s great to have him with us. Yes, we planned to use spinners against Miller and Klaasen, and they both delivered perfectly. Honestly, it does feel a bit easier (laughs). As I mentioned in the press conference, the team has simplified my job, and everyone understands their roles well.

PreMatchCommentary:
India's juggernaut rolls into Gqeberha with the scent of series dominance in their nostrils. After Sanju Samson's masterclass lit up Durban in the opener, the visitors now have their sights set on a commanding 2-0 lead at St George's Park.The Proteas find themselves in familiar troubled waters, their batting lineup still dizzy from the spin web woven by Varun Chakaravarthy and Ravi Bishnoi. But write off Aiden Markram's men at your peril – this fortress of St George's Park has been their happy hunting ground, with three wins from their last four T20Is.South Africa's cavalry arrives in the form of Heinrich Klaasen and David Miller, two explosive game-changers who could turn the tide. Yet, the hosts' Achilles heel against spin remains a concern that needs urgent addressing.Team India, meanwhile, shows no signs of tinkering with their winning formula, though opener Abhishek Sharma's form raises eyebrows. The visitors' batting arsenal looks locked and loaded with Suryakumar Yadav and Tilak Varma in murderous form.As the Sunday showdown beckons, one burning question remains: Can the Proteas solve their spin puzzle, or will India's tweakers once again prove to be their nemesis? 


 

Pitch Report | Ashwell Prince & Shaun Pollock:
"It’s overcast here in Gqeberha, and there’s a chance of rain. The pitch looks slightly different from the usual surface, with a bit more grass cover than we’re accustomed to. The conditions have changed slightly with the cloud cover and recent rain, which will likely favour the seamers. The grass should help the seam bowlers get some movement, and though it’s firm and solid, batters should feel encouraged too. There isn’t expected to be much spin tonight, but this venue often holds something for the spinners despite appearances. South Africa struggled against spin in the first T20I, so it’ll be interesting to see if that plays a role here. The surface is hard underneath, meaning the ball should carry nicely through to the keeper.It looks like a good pitch to the eye, with something for both batters and seamers. The key question: will India’s two spinners enjoy these conditions? With rain looming, teams might prefer to bowl first." 



TOSS UPDATE: South Africa Won the Toss and Elected to field 

Aiden Markram | South Africa Captain:

In a gripping low-scorer, South Africa clawed their way back into the series, chasing down India's modest 124 with 3 wickets in hand and an over to spare, leveling the contest 1-1. Opting to bowl, the Proteas' disciplined attack stifled India from the outset. Early dismissals of Samson, Sharma and Yadav left the visitors reeling at 15/3. Pandya's gritty 39* lifted India to 124/6, but it seemed under par. The South African chase stumbled as spin wizard Chakravarthy spun a web, his 5/17 leaving the hosts 86/7. However, local hero Stubbs (47*) and Coetzee engineered a vital 42-run stand to take SA over the line. Despite Chakravarthy's heroics, India's pacers couldn't close it out, allowing the SA tail to hold their nerve. This absorbing encounter sets up a mouthwatering decider, with both sides showcasing resilience and match-winners. South Africa's bowlers first set the tone, before Stubbs' composure and Chakravarthy's brilliance provided the drama in a low-scoring thriller. The series is evenly poised, primed for an enthralling finale 

Tristan Stubbs | Player of the Match:
"We were lucky that the required rate never got out of hand. I aimed to get around 30 off the last three overs, and with some help from the dew and Coetzee’s big shots, we managed to cross the line. Playing here, with the crowd behind us, is always special. Now that it’s 1-1, we have everything to play for in the next match." 

Suryakumar Yadav | India Captain:
"We always back whatever total we put up, and I reminded the team to fight till the end, regardless of the score. In T20, defending 125 isn’t ideal, but I’m proud of how we bowled. Varun Chakaravarthy’s five-wicket haul was remarkable, especially under pressure defending a low total. He’s worked hard, and it showed today. We’re heading to Jo’burg with the series tied 1-1, and it promises to be exciting cricket." 

Aiden Markram | South Africa Captain:
"I thought we bowled well today; the bowlers stuck to the plans, and I’m proud of them. Our batting wasn’t great as we lost wickets in clusters, which made things tricky. Thankfully, my finger’s doing fine. Hats off to Coetzee and Stubbs—they came off a break and showed great hunger. To deliver such a performance against India is always satisfying. Levelling the series going into the Highveld is fantastic, even if it wasn’t the way we ideally wanted to get over the line."

PreMatchCommentary:
The T20I series between India and South Africa moves to SuperSport Park, Centurion, perfectly poised at 1-1 after two contrasting encounters that showcase the quality of both sides.

India's commanding performance at Kingsmead featured Sanju Samson's masterful century (107 off 50), demonstrating their batting firepower. The spin duo of Varun Chakravarthy and Ravi Bishnoi has added another dimension to their bowling arsenal, with Chakravarthy's exceptional spells (3/25 and 5/17) highlighting India's versatility in different conditions.

South Africa showed their resilience at St George's Park, with Tristan Stubbs' composed 47* leading a calculated chase. The Proteas' pace battery, spearheaded by Gerald Coetzee, has consistently challenged the batters, while Keshav Maharaj's economic bowling has provided crucial control.

The series now shifts to Centurion's pace-friendly terrain, where batting historically flourishes at 9.46 runs per over. Both teams have momentum to build upon - India's sophisticated spin strategy and dynamic batting lineup, matched against South Africa's pace prowess and home conditions advantage.

With the addition of Lutho Sipamla to the Proteas squad, the stage is set for an enthralling contest between two sides showcasing cricket's next generation of talent. 

TOSS UPDATE: South Africa won the Toss and Elected to Field 

Aiden Markram | South Africa Captain:
"We'll bowl first again. The wicket looks good, and it tends to play better under lights, so we're sticking with that plan. Our last game wasn’t our best, but it’s a positive that we still managed to come out on top. It’s about finding rhythm and time in the middle, and we back our players to perform. We’ve made one change: Nqaba Peter is out, and Lutho Sipamla comes in." 

Suryakumar Yadav | India Captain:
"We’ve done well batting first in the last two games, and we wanted to put runs on the board anyway. The boys have shown up with clear plans and executed them well, so I’m happy with how they’re performing. The message is simple—stick to your skills, go out there, and enjoy yourselves. They’ve really made my job easier. We’ve made one change: Ramandeep Singh is making his debut, while Avesh Khan sits out. Avesh has been great for us, but we needed to make room, so Ramandeep gets his chance."

India clinched a thrilling 11-run win over South Africa, taking a 2-1 lead in the series. Batting first, India posted a formidable 219/6 in 20 overs. Tilak Varma was the standout performer, scoring an unbeaten 107 off 56 balls, including eight fours and seven sixes. Abhishek Sharma supported with a brisk 50 off 25 balls. Despite wickets falling at regular intervals, India maintained a high scoring rate, aided by Ramandeep Singh’s quick 15 off 6 balls towards the end.

South Africa’s chase was spirited, especially with Marco Jansen blazing his way to a 17-ball 54, smashing four fours and five sixes. Heinrich Klaasen added a swift 41 off 22 balls, keeping the visitors in the hunt. However, India’s bowlers held their nerve, with Arshdeep Singh taking 3/37 in his 4 overs, including the crucial wicket of Jansen in the final overs.

While Hardik Pandya and Axar Patel chipped in with a wicket each, it was Arshdeep’s breakthrough at critical moments that sealed the game for India. The hosts now lead the series 2-1, putting them in a strong position heading into the next match. 


Tilak Varma | Player of the Match:
"Yes, I’m fine! The catch was tricky under the lights, but I’m doing well now. Honestly, I can’t describe it—it was a dream to score a hundred for my country, and I’m really happy. All credit to our captain, Suryakumar Yadav, for giving me the opportunity at number three. He encouraged me before the game, saying I had the potential for this role. Huge thanks to him for the support." 


Aiden Markram | South Africa Captain:
"Really proud of the team, especially with the contributions from the middle and lower middle order. Here in Centurion, when the middle order steps up, it usually sets you up for a strong finish. Once a partnership builds, things can escalate quickly. At this venue, you almost expect to chase totals down—it becomes an over-by-over battle. Marco was fantastic in the last over; if you keep doing the right things, success follows. The batters can take confidence from this, and the bowlers will look to fine-tune their skills before we head to Joburg." 

Suryakumar Yadav | India Captain: 
"As captain, I felt we played the brand of cricket we set out to play. We’ve been talking about playing the way we do for our franchises or state teams, and I believe staying clear-minded is crucial. Watching our batters perform like they did today made my job so much easier, and it feels like we’re moving in the right direction as a team. The energy, aggression, and intent on display were really satisfying to see. Tilak Varma actually came to my room before the game and asked if he could bat at number 3, and I’m really happy for him and his family that it worked out so well."

Welcome to the Live coverage of the 4th and final T20 in this series between India and South Africa from The Wanderers, Johannesburg. Aiden Markram | South Africa Captain:

India delivered a clinical performance, securing a commanding 135-run victory over South Africa to clinch the bilateral T20 series 3-1. After opting to bat first, the visitors put on a batting masterclass, with Sanju Samson and Tilak Varma scoring majestic centuries to power India to 283/1.

India's bowlers then produced a devastating display, with Arshdeep Singh and Hardik Pandya running through the South African top order. Despite a spirited fightback from David Miller and Tristan Stubbs, the hosts were eventually bowled out for 148, handing India a comprehensive series triumph.

This victory highlighted India's all-round dominance, with key players stepping up in both departments. The result also underscored the depth and adaptability of the Indian squad, as they continue to assert their supremacy in T20 cricket.  



Tilak Varma | Player of the Match and Series:
"This inning was crucial for the team and the series. I wanted to back myself, stay calm, and follow my basics. I never imagined scoring a century in South Africa. I'm grateful to God and captain Suryakumar for the opportunity to bat at number 3. After being injured for the last 2 months, scoring this hundred was a special moment." 

Aiden Markram | South Africa Captain
 "We were outplayed by India. We were hoping to level the series, but credit to them for their clinical display. You can't just hit the stumps these days - you need to use the crease, bowl wider, and challenge the batters."
 

Suryakumar Yadav | India Captain:
"There's no secret to adapting to situations. Our plans were clear from the start, and we wanted to continue the way we played on our last tour. The batting performances from Sanju, Tilak, and Abhishek were simply amazing. The wicket had something in it after the temperature dropped, and our bowlers executed our plans to perfection. Winning the T20 WC has given us a big boost, and this series victory in South Africa will stay with me forever. The coaching staff gave the boys the freedom to express themselves, and that's what they did."

CompetitionName: Border Gavaskar Trophy 2024-25
PreMatchCommentary:
The cricketing world is abuzz as India and Australia prepare for a high-stakes Border-Gavaskar Trophy series, commencing on November 22, 2024, and concluding on January 7, 2025. This five-match Test series is pivotal for both teams, with significant implications for the ICC World Test Championship (WTC) standings.


India, currently second on the WTC table, faces a formidable challenge. To secure a spot in the WTC final, they must clinch four out of the five Tests—a daunting task, especially on Australian soil. The series opener at Perth's Optus Stadium adds to the intrigue, as Australia boasts an unbeaten record at this venue. Compounding India's challenges, captain Rohit Sharma is unavailable for the first Test due to personal reasons, and opener Shubman Gill has been sidelined with a thumb injury. In their absence, vice-captain Jasprit Bumrah will lead the side, with seasoned campaigner Virat Kohli anchoring a batting lineup infused with youthful talent eager to make their mark.


Despite a recent 3-0 series loss to New Zealand, India remain optimistic. The team is determined to reverse their fortunes and draw inspiration from their previous successes Down Under. The blend of experience and fresh energy could be the catalyst they need to challenge Australia's dominance.


Australia, perched atop the WTC standings, enters the series with confidence. Although they haven't played a Test in over six months, their formidable record at the Optus Stadium and the prospect of a subsequent series against Sri Lanka keep them focused. To secure their place in the WTC final, Australia needs four wins from their remaining seven matches. The team is keen to reclaim the Border-Gavaskar Trophy, having lost the last two home series to India.


As the top two teams in Test cricket collide, fans can anticipate a series brimming with intensity, skill, and drama. Will India's resilience and hunger for redemption prevail, or will Australia's home advantage and strategic acumen secure them the series? Cricket enthusiasts worldwide await the unfolding of this epic contest.

Head-To-Head in BGT:
In the 56 matches contested between the two teams, India edged out Australia with 24 wins to 20 wins, while 12 of the other matches ended in a draw.





TOSS UPDATE: India won the Toss and Elected to Bat First   
 

Jasprit Bumrah | India Captain:
"We are going to bat first. It looks like a good wicket, and we’ll need to adapt to the conditions and put a solid total on the board.Our preparation for this Test match has been excellent. We also had a good experience playing at the WACA recently.We played a Test here in 2018, so we know what to expect. The pitch tends to get quicker as the game progresses. Nitish Kumar Reddy makes his debut as a fast-bowling all-rounder. We have four fast bowlers in the lineup, along with Washi." 
 

Pat Cummins | Australia Captain:
"Yeah, that's right. It was a 50-50 decision. The sun hasn't been out much, so it's fine. Any format between these two sides is always fiercely competitive. Test matches, in particular, are even more intense and closely contested. Nathan McSweeney makes his Test debut today and will bat at the top of the order. The rest of the team remains unchanged."

In a remarkable display of resilience and skill, India overcame a first-innings collapse to secure their largest victory against Australia - a historic 295-run win at Perth Stadium, taking a 1-0 lead in the Border-Gavaskar Trophy 2024/25 and surging to World Test Championship table's summit.

After being bundled out for 150 on a green Day 1 track, India's fightback began with Bumrah's fierce spell reducing Australia to 67/7 by stumps. The visitors eventually secured a vital 46-run first-innings lead.

The match transformed dramatically as openers Yashasvi Jaiswal (161) and KL Rahul (77) crafted a record-breaking partnership - the highest by an Indian opening pair in Australia. Jaiswal became only the third Indian to score a century on debut in Australia, while Virat Kohli's masterful 30th Test hundred (100*) helped set an imposing 534-run target.

Despite Travis Head's counter-attacking 89, Australia's fortress finally crumbled on Day 4. The hosts, who had never lost at Perth Stadium in four previous Tests, were dismissed for 238, with Bumrah and Siraj leading India's charge.

India's victory ranks alongside their famous wins at Gabba 2021 and Adelaide 2003. Captain Bumrah's leadership and bowling excellence epitomized India's dominance, turning early adversity into their biggest win against Australia - a historic triumph that takes them to No.1 in the WTC standings 
 

Pat Cummins | Australia Captain:
"It’s fairly disappointing, especially given how well we prepared for the game. But cricket is like that—you have to get back on the horse quickly after a loss. We’ll take a couple of days off and then return to the field in Adelaide.We didn’t really give ourselves a chance, particularly during that tricky period on Day 1. If we had navigated it better, things could have turned out differently. There are plenty of experienced players in the dressing room, and this is just the start of a big summer. It’s a sample size of one, and I’m confident we’ll bounce back. Lots of conversations ahead to set things right." 
 

Jasprit Bumrah  | India Captain & Player of the Match:
"Feeling very happy. We were under pressure in the first innings, but the way we responded was fantastic. I remember playing here in 2018—the wicket back then started soft, but this one was less spicy. Our preparation paid off well. I kept reminding everyone to trust their abilities, and it worked.Jaiswal played his best Test innings so far; his shot selection and judgment were excellent. As for Virat, I never felt he was out of form. It’s tough to judge on challenging pitches, but he looked solid in the nets and performed well. The crowd’s support was amazing as always—it lifts us, and we feed off that energy."

PreMatchCommentary:
Welcome to the most awaited pink-ball Test of the BGT 2024-25, as a buoyant Indian team aims to strengthen their grip on the series at the historic Adelaide Oval.After their commanding performance in Perth, Team India enters this day-night contest with renewed confidence. Captain Rohit Sharma's return fortifies an already formidable lineup, with the skipper opting to bat in the middle order. This tactical decision maintains the momentum of the successful opening combination of KL Rahul and Yashasvi Jaiswal, who have shown remarkable understanding at the top.The Adelaide Oval holds special significance for India, particularly Virat Kohli, whose record at this venue stands testament to his mastery in Australian conditions. His recent form, coupled with the team's comprehensive preparation in the practice match against the PM's XI, positions India strongly for this crucial encounter.India's bowling arsenal, led by the exceptional Jasprit Bumrah and Mohammed Siraj, has already demonstrated their ability to dominate in Australian conditions.The visitors' preparation has been meticulous, with specific focus on adapting to the unique challenges of pink-ball cricket. The return of Shubman Gill, who looked in sublime touch during the practice match, further strengthens India's batting credentials.As the sun sets over Adelaide's picturesque skyline, this promises to be a fascinating contest where India's tactical acumen and batting prowess meet the challenges of day-night Test cricket. With momentum firmly on their side, Team India looks primed to script another memorable chapter in their Australian sojourn

 

Pitch Report | Matthew Hayden & Sunil Gavaskar

"About a week ago, there was a lot of grass on the pitch, but much of it has been trimmed over the last few days. There’s still around 6 mm left, which should offer plenty of assistance to the fast bowlers when the ball is new and hard. After that initial period, Adelaide pitches are typically good for batting. It looks like it could seam around quite a bit early on. Eventually, batting becomes easier, but bowlers often dominate late on Day 2, and averages dip. I’ve also noticed lines running up and down the wicket, with thicker grass cover than last year." 

 


TOSS UPDATE: India Won the Toss and Elected to Bat 

 

Rohit Sharma | India Captain:
"We’d like to bat first. The pitch looks good—slightly dry but with enough grass for some early carry. As the game progresses, it should become better for batting and offer something for everyone, so we’re in for a good contest. I’ve been here for about two weeks now, had good net sessions, and even played a practice game, so I’m ready. The team’s mood is vibrant. We put in a great performance in Perth and want to carry that momentum. It’s a long series, and while breaks are welcome, maintaining the rhythm is crucial. We’ve made three changes. I’m back, Gill is back, and Ashwin returns in place of Washi, Padikkal, and Jurel. I’ll be batting in the middle order—it’s different, but I’m ready for the challenge."


Pat Cummins | Australia Captain:
"Yes, we would have chosen to bat first. But on Day 1 with a pink ball, it might nip around a bit. It’s always nice to start fresh here—we’ve had success at this venue. Every series against India seems to bring that challenge, and though we weren’t at our best last week, preparations have been good, and the boys are ready. There might be more swing today since it’s muggy, but hopefully, it's not as bad as yesterday. We’ve made one change: Josh Hazlewood is out, and Scott Boland comes in."

The hosts secured a 10-wicket victory in the Pink Ball Test, completing the match in just 171.5 overs.Mitchell Starc (6/48) made early inroads after India chose to bat, restricting them to 180. Travis Head's attacking 140 helped Australia post 337, building a significant first-innings lead.Young Nitish Reddy showed promise with twin scores of 42, but India's total of 175 in the second innings meant Australia needed just 19 to win. Cummins and Boland were the key performers with the ball.The series now stands level at 1-1 as both teams head to Brisbane, with momentum shifting between the sides in what's proving to be an engaging Border-Gavaskar Trophy 
 

Travis Head | Player Of The Match:
"It feels great to get some runs here. It’s just another game, but I felt in good touch last week, and it’s nice to continue that form.The dressing room atmosphere is fantastic, despite what people might say. Nothing is ever guaranteed in this game, but it’s great to have this momentum. Now it’s about moving forward and building on it.Pat Cummins gives me a lot of confidence, and I saw the second new ball as a great opportunity to score quickly. I just tried to make the most of it, and luckily, I managed to get things rolling."  


 

Rohit Sharma | India Captain:
"It was a disappointing week for us. Australia simply played better cricket. We had our moments, but failing to capitalize on them cost us the game.What we did in Perth was special, and we wanted to replicate that here. But every Test comes with its own set of challenges. We knew it would be tough, but credit to Australia – they were the better side in this match.There’s not much time before the next Test, and as a team, we’re eager to reflect on what worked for us in Perth and what we did well the last time we played at the Gabba. We’ll take those lessons and aim to bounce back."


 

Pat Cummins | Australia Captain:
"It’s been a fantastic week. We were far from the team we wanted to be in Perth, but this is exactly how we aim to play.It feels great to pick up a few wickets, and I’m really happy with the fifer. Starc was amazing out there – he’s been doing it consistently for over a decade, and I feel very lucky and privileged to share the field with him.Head loves batting here, no doubt about it. When he came in, the game could have gone either way, but he turned the momentum in our favor brilliantly.The lead was crucial for us. Bowling under lights was a perfect scenario – the ball moved a lot, and it played into our hands. While the pink ball does a bit more under lights, the key was securing that big first-innings lead.Scotty was fantastic, seamlessly fitting in as he always does. Hopefully, Joshy will be ready for the next Test, but if not, Scotty is just incredible.

PreMatchCommentary:
The Brisbane Cricket Ground (Gabba) is ready to witness a gripping encounter as Australia and India prepare for the third Test, with the series tied at 1-1. Both teams will be looking to take the lead in what promises to be an epic battle, and the stakes couldn’t be higher.


Australia enters the contest riding high after their resounding 10-wicket win over India at the Adelaide Oval. Their dominance with the pink ball has set the tone for the series, and they’ll look to continue that momentum as they return to their fortress—the Gabba. Despite their recent strong record here, Australia is haunted by the fact they’ve lost two out of the last four games played at this very venue. The hosts will be eager to put that behind them and showcase their strengths. Travis Head has been sublime, scoring 89 in Perth and 140 in Adelaide, while Marnus Labuschagne has been another contributor. The bowling attack has been firing on all cylinders, with Mitchell Starc taking a match-winning six wickets in the first innings and Pat Cummins claiming a five-fer in the second. Scott Boland has also been key, dismissing Virat Kohli and Rohit Sharma in either of the innings.


On the other hand, India enters this Test with plenty to prove after their batting struggles in three of the four innings so far. Despite this, there have been moments of brilliance, notably from Nitish Reddy, who has been positive, and Kohli and Jaiswal, scoring centuries in Perth. Jasprit Bumrah has been India’s standout bowler with 12 wickets to his name, while Mohammad Siraj has also contributed with a four-wicket haul in Adelaide. India’s historic three-wicket win at the Gabba last time is still fresh in their minds—will they replicate that remarkable achievement?


The series is poised for an intense showdown. Will Pat Cummins and his men continue their dominance, or will India deliver another stunning performance like they did at the Gabba last time? The battle for supremacy is on—who will rise to the occasion and take the lead in this high-stakes contest? 


TOSS UPDATE : India Won the Toss and Elected to Field  
 

Rohit Sharma | India Captain:
"We’ve decided to bowl first. It’s a bit overcast, and the surface looks soft. It might stick a bit, so we want to take advantage of these conditions.There’s a lot to play for. Both teams have played well so far, and we’re looking to bring our best. We know we’ve been playing good cricket, but we need to capitalize on key moments, something we didn’t do in the last Test.The guys are excited and eager to do well for their country. They want to get out there and make an impact. The surface does look a bit soft, and with the overcast conditions, we expect it to improve as the game progresses.We’ve made two changes: Jadeja and Akash Deep come in for Harshit Rana and Ashwin" 

Pat Cummins | Australia Captain:
"I believe this looks like a good wicket, and I’m hoping we can put some solid runs on the board. It’s going to be a sell-out crowd, and I expect it to be pretty loud. We had a great week in Adelaide, and I’m really happy with how things played out. Everyone played their part. The weather in Brisbane hasn’t impacted our preparations, and we’ve had a good lead-up to this game. We love playing here at the Gabba, and we’re excited for this match. The early finish in Adelaide gave us a couple of extra days to prepare.We’ve made one change—Josh Hazlewood comes in for Scott Boland"

The third Test between Australia and India at Brisbane concluded in a rain-affected draw, leaving the series evenly poised at 1-1 with two matches remaining. Australia, after put into bat first, amassed a formidable 445, propelled by centuries from Steve Smith and Travis Head. Smith's 101 marked a return to form, while Head's aggressive 152 showcased his growing stature in the lineup. India's spearhead, Jasprit Bumrah, was the standout bowler, claiming six wickets for 76 runs.


In reply, India faced early setbacks, slipping to 74 for 5. However, resilient half-centuries from KL Rahul (84) and Ravindra Jadeja (75) steadied the innings. A crucial last-wicket partnership of 47 between Bumrah and debutant Akash Deep enabled India to reach 260, narrowly avoiding the follow-on. Australian pacers Pat Cummins and Mitchell Starc were instrumental, securing four and three wickets respectively.


Persistent rain disruptions played a significant role throughout the match. Australia, with a first-innings lead of 185, declared their second innings at 89 for 7, setting India a target of 275. Bumrah continued his impressive form, taking three wickets, while Akash Deep and Mohammed Siraj shared two apiece.


India began their chase confidently, reaching 8 without loss in 2.1 overs before rain intervened once more. The inclement weather persisted, forcing the match to end in a draw. This result keeps the series level, setting the stage for a compelling fourth Test.

Rohit Sharma: India Captain


"We'll take this result. While the weather interruptions weren't ideal, heading to Melbourne with the series level at 1-1 gives us real momentum. After lunch on Day 4, we were in a tricky spot and needed someone to step up - with the weather forecast in mind, we knew we weren't going to get a full game in.

Impressed with Jadeja's performance, and Rahul's batting at the top was outstanding. The partnership between Akash Deep and Bumrah was fantastic to watch - they've been putting in so much effort on their batting in practice sessions.

Bumrah was exceptional with the ball, and Akash Deep brings such great energy - he's always looking to make an impact in every aspect of the game. Though he's still finding his feet in international cricket, his work ethic has been tremendous. It's great to see the senior players in the group helping guide him. His batting performance showed exactly the kind of character we want in this team - someone who's willing to fight for every run."



Pat Cummins: Australia Captain

"We'd prefer to be leading 2-1, but with all the rain interruptions, that was out of our control. Getting that massive total on the board put us in a commanding position from the start. Feel for Josh Hazlewood - it was just one of those situations, though the rain breaks actually worked in our favor since Mitch and I could keep going.

The day 5 pitch had its moments of variable bounce, though it hadn't seen much action. The new ball definitely posed some challenges. Really proud of how Smith and Head batted - they were exceptional, and Alex Carey's contribution was crucial too. Nathan Lyon looked in great rhythm, Starc kept picking up important wickets - pretty much everything went according to plan.

The Boxing Day atmosphere at the MCG with a packed house is something special - it's one of those uniquely Australian cricket moments that gets you excited from the moment you wake up."


Travis Head: Player Of The Match


"To be honest, it feels like ages since I was at the crease. I'm pleased I could make an impact and help set up the team's position with my batting in the first innings. The pitch presented some real challenges, but I managed to adapt my game as needed and I'm satisfied with how I worked through those different phases. I think I've been reading the conditions pretty well throughout this series, and I'm particularly happy with the rhythm I've found in my batting.

The partnership with Smith was great - we kept the communication simple and clear. Seeing him batting so smoothly at the other end boosted my confidence, and we clicked well together out there. My approach when I first come in is always about figuring out what the situation demands and finding solutions to whatever challenges come up. Physically, I'm carrying a bit of soreness but should be good to go for the next match."

PreMatchCommentary:
With the series tantalizingly poised at 1-1, the stage is set for a blockbuster Boxing Day Test at the iconic Melbourne Cricket Ground on December 26, 2024. Both teams will be hungry to seize this opportunity and claim the crucial 12 World Test Championship points up for grabs.


Australia enters this clash riding high on Travis Head’s remarkable form. The dynamic batter has amassed an impressive 409 runs this series, anchoring the hosts with his brilliance. On the other side, India’s hopes rest heavily on the shoulders of Jasprit Bumrah, whose 21 wickets have been a testament to his world-class skill and unwavering consistency.


India’s stellar record at the MCG—having triumphed in their last two appearances at the venue—adds intrigue to the contest. However, Australia’s recent resurgence and the home advantage promise to make this encounter an enthralling battle.


Will India continue to dominate in Melbourne and inch closer to series glory, or will Australia channel their momentum to take the lead? Fans can expect an unforgettable Test match with both sides brimming with talent and determination. who will emerge victorious in this gripping showdown? 

TOSS UPDATE: Australia Won the Toss and Elected to Bat 
 

Pat Cummins | Australia Captain:
"We’re going to bat today. The pitch looks good with a bit of grass, and the sun is out, so it feels firm. Being 1-1 is just what everyone wanted—especially the fans.After Christmas, we’re eager to get going again. Sam Konstas is making his debut and will open the batting. Scott Boland replaces Josh Hazlewood." 

 

Rohit Sharma | India Captain:
"We would have chosen to bat first as well, but we must bowl effectively. With the series at 1-1, there’s everything to play for. It’s the perfect stage to demonstrate our team’s character. Whatever the circumstances, we have to fight. It’s a fresh day, and we’re excited. We showed good resilience in the last match.We’ve made one change—Shubman Gill misses out, and Washington Sundar comes in. Yes, I’ll be opening the batting."

Australia secured a commanding 184-run victory over India in the fourth Test, going 2-1 up in the series. Opting to bat first, Australia posted a formidable 474 in the first innings, powered by a superb century from Steve Smith and vital half-centuries from Usman Khawaja and Marnus Labuschagne. Jasprit Bumrah was the standout bowler for India, claiming four wickets.

India’s reply saw Nitish Kumar Reddy shine with a brilliant century, supported by Yashasvi Jaiswal’s steady 82 and Washington Sundar’s gritty fifty. However, the Australian bowlers, led by Pat Cummins, Scott Boland, and Nathan Lyon, each with three wickets, ensured India could only manage 369, giving Australia a crucial 105-run lead.

In their second innings, Australia added 234 runs, with Labuschagne top-scoring with 70 and Bumrah picking up a fifer. India faced a daunting target of 340 on the final day. The chase began poorly as India lost key batters before lunch. Despite a resilient partnership between Rishabh Pant and Jaiswal in the second session, India’s batting crumbled in the evening, all out for 155. Boland and Cummins were once again the wreckers-in-chief, picking three wickets each.

Rohit Sharma (India Captain):

"This loss cuts deep. We didn't enter this match planning to surrender - our intention was to battle until the final ball, but things didn't unfold that way. While the last two sessions are fresh in everyone's mind, we need to look at the complete picture. The opportunities were there throughout the match; we had Australia on the ropes at 90/6. Despite knowing cricket can be unforgiving, our goal is to rise above challenging situations. I spent time in my room afterward, reflecting on our strategies, and I believe we gave it our all. That final partnership really turned the tide against us. Chasing 340 was always going to be a mountain to climb. Our plan was to build a foundation and keep wickets intact heading into those crucial final sessions, but I must acknowledge their exceptional bowling. We had our sights set on the target, but failed to establish the platform we needed. Winning Test matches requires finding different pathways to success, and we fell short in discovering those routes.

Regarding NKR, he's experiencing these conditions for the first time, and they can be incredibly challenging. His display of character and technical prowess was impressive. He possesses all the qualities needed for success at this level, and I'm hopeful his journey will be one of continuous growth. He has the complete support of this team behind him.

As for Bumrah, his performance was nothing short of exceptional. We've witnessed his evolution over the years, and his impact here was remarkable. He's never been one to chase statistics - his focus is purely on serving the country and contributing to the team's success. Unfortunately, he didn't receive the support he deserved from the other end."

Pat Cummins (Australia Captain and Player of The Match):
"This Test match was simply extraordinary - I'd rank it among the finest I've ever participated in. The atmosphere created by the crowd throughout the week was incredible, and being part of such an occasion was special. I owe a lot to Marnus for his guidance during my second innings, and I'm pleased I could play my part. Steve's batting was remarkable - considering we won the toss and faced challenging conditions on day one, posting a total in the high 400s was a fantastic achievement.

Our batting strategy was deliberately focused on eliminating any possibility of an Indian victory. With a comfortable run cushion, we maximized our opportunities to crowd the batsmen with close-in fielders. We've invested significant effort in developing our lower-order batting skills, primarily focusing on understanding how to bowl effectively to opposition batters, but also ensuring we can contribute meaningful runs. The over rate situation influenced our decision to bring Travis in - we thought that might help us manage that aspect better.

Smith's performance was a masterclass in batting on this surface. His brilliant innings, combined with some crucial catches in the slips - something that often goes unnoticed - really showcased his value. There's a great feeling of satisfaction in the dressing room right now. We're going to take some time to enjoy this victory before shifting our focus to Sydney."

A decade-long wait ends at the SCG as Webster's elegant lofted drive seals both the Border-Gavaskar Trophy and World Test Championship final berth. The debutant's unbeaten partnership with Head steering Australia home in a chase of 162, transforming early pressure into calculated triumph.The match's complexion shifted dramatically from Pant's blazing 61 off 33 balls to Boland's masterful six-wicket haul. Krishna's fierce spell injected brief hope - removing Smith on 9,999 Test runs and reducing Australia to 58/3 - but the target proved insufficient without Bumrah's services in the final innings.The series' defining narrative emerges through contrasts: Bumrah's record 32 wickets stand tall amidst India's batting fragilities, and Australia's resilience after Perth defeat powers their 3-1 victory. From Adelaide's turnaround to Melbourne's dominance, culminating in Sydney's swift three-day finish on an unexpectedly spicy pitch. For Australia, the victory heals past wounds and sets up a Lord's date with South Africa to defend their WTC crown.  


Scott Boland  | Player Of The Match: "An incredible couple of months. Didn't expect to play such a crucial role, but stayed prepared. Beating India 3-1 is special - hasn't happened in a long time. Just happy to contribute whenever called upon." 


Jasprit Bumrah | Player Of The Series and India Captain: "Sometimes you have to respect what your body tells you. Missing the spiciest pitch of the series was frustrating, but that's cricket. Our bowlers showed tremendous character stepping up when we were one short. The belief was always there. Congratulations to Australia - they fought exceptionally well. We'll take these lessons forward." 


Pat Cummins | Australia Captain: "This is special - the Border-Gavaskar Trophy was the one missing from our cabinet. I am immensely proud of how we bounced back after Perth, staying clear with our plans throughout. Using our entire squad proved crucial in a five-Test series - three debutants stepping up at different moments, especially Webster's magnificent debut here.The key to beating India was our senior players delivering in crucial moments, while maintaining adaptability with our plans. Special mention to Rohit and Bumrah - this series showcased Test cricket at its finest. And to end it on Jane McGrath Day in Sydney makes it even more meaningful.Will definitely go down as my favorite series to lead. Privileged to captain this special group."

PreMatchCommentary:
Cricket fans worldwide are eagerly awaiting the epic clash between India and England as they prepare for a thrilling five-match T20I series, starting January 22 at the iconic Eden Gardens. The action doesn’t stop there, as a three-match ODI series will follow, serving as a prelude to the Champions Trophy.


Defending champions India, led by the electrifying Suryakumar Yadav, are riding high on their recent successes. The team has won every series since their triumphant T20 World Cup 2024 campaign, showcasing their brand of aggressive and fearless cricket—aptly called "SKYball." With Suryakumar’s innovative batting and a team built around attacking intent, India is looking to dominate on home soil. The return of veteran pacer Mohammed Shami adds a new dimension, strengthening their formidable squad.


England, under new head coach Brendon McCullum, are introducing their bold "Bazball" philosophy to the shortest format. Led by the explosive Jos Buttler, the visitors boast a perfect blend of experience and youthful talent. This is England’s first series in their new era, and they are determined to prove their mettle against the hosts.


As both teams eye the T20 World Cup 2026 , co-hosted by India and Sri Lanka, this series is more than just a bilateral contest. It’s a stage for SKYball and Bazball to collide, showcasing two revolutionary cricketing styles. Will India’s fearless SKYball dominate, or can England’s daring Bazball reign supreme? Fans are bracing for a spectacle that promises unforgettable moments.
 

Pitch Report by Deep Dasgupta and Nick Knight:
"The six-hitting festival begins today at the iconic Eden Gardens Stadium. Over the last two years, this venue has averaged 10 sixes per innings in T20 games, making it a paradise for big hitters. The dimensions are batter-friendly—59m and 66m square boundaries, with 75m straight down the ground.

The pitch has a nice tinge of green, though it’s not overly green. It won’t do much, but there will be enough in it for the bowlers early on. The tall England bowlers could extract some bounce and carry from the surface, which will be an advantage for them.

Traditionally, Eden Gardens is a high-scoring venue, and we expect plenty of runs today. The surface looks a bit drier and white-ish right now but will likely darken as the game progresses due to the dew factor. This means the ball will skid on, adding to the challenge for bowlers.

There’s not much on offer for the spinners, as it doesn’t seem like it will spin much. With more carry and pace, batters will look to dominate, and there will be pressure on the bowlers to execute their plans perfectly."



Toss Update: India won the toss and have opted to chase! 

Suryakumar Yadav:
"We will look to bowl first. The wicket looks a bit sticky, and there will be dew later on, which will make it heavier as the game progresses. The boys have been amazing, and the preparations have gone really well. We’re looking forward to this series—it’s going to be a great competition between both sides.

It’s a good headache to have, but we want to stick to our strengths and play to our game plan."

Jos Buttler:
"It looks like a good wicket, and we’re sure it’s going to be an exciting match. There will be some dew around, which might play a part later. This is a great ground, and it’s always an honour to play against India in these conditions.

Everyone in the squad is in a good place, and it’s nice to have the team together. With McCullum taking charge, his experience brings a lot to the group. It’s going to be a challenge, but we’re up for it. There’s some incredible talent on both sides, which should make for a fantastic contest.

Saqib Mahmood, Brydon Carse, Jamie Smith, and Rehan Ahmed will miss out for this game."

India showcased their dominance with a commanding seven-wicket win over England in the opening T20I at Eden Gardens, taking a 1-0 lead in the five-match series. Put into bat first, England struggled to build momentum against a disciplined Indian bowling attack and were bowled out for 132. Jos Buttler was the standout performer for the visitors, playing a resilient knock of 68, but lacked support from the other end.

India’s bowling unit delivered an all-round performance, with Varun Chakaravarthy leading the way with a brilliant three-wicket haul. Arshdeep Singh, Hardik Pandya, and Axar Patel complemented him well, each picking up two wickets to restrict England to a modest total.

Chasing 133, India’s batting lineup made light work of the target. Abhishek Sharma stole the show with a dazzling 79 off just 34 balls, playing an array of impressive shots to put India firmly in control. Sanju Samson provided solid support with a quickfire 26 off 20 deliveries, ensuring a smooth chase. The hosts crossed the finish line in just 12.5 overs, completing a thoroughly professional performance.

Jos Buttler  (England Skipper):

"There was a little bit in the wicket early on, and unfortunately, we lost a couple of wickets. Jofra (Archer) always looks good—he’s an absolute superstar. Watching him and Wood operate together is really exciting; they bring so much to the team.

From venue to venue, it’s crucial to assess the conditions quickly and adapt your game accordingly. Personally, I’m really enjoying the environment within the team. I’ve always been a big fan of Brendon McCullum, and it’s fantastic to be working with him. His approach and insights have been invaluable."

Suryakumar Yadav (India Skipper):

"The energy after winning the toss set the benchmark for the game. The bowlers had clear plans and executed them brilliantly, and the way we batted was the icing on the cake.

We followed a similar approach to what we did in South Africa, where Hardik took responsibility with the new ball, giving us the cushion to play the extra spinner. Varun's preparations have been spot-on, and Arshdeep has stepped up by taking extra responsibility, which is great to see.

There’s a lot of freedom within the team, and we want to play a bit differently, pushing boundaries to improve. Fielding has been a key focus for us—we’ve been working really hard on it. Taking those half-chances and making a difference in the field can be crucial in tight games."
 

Varun Chakaravarthy (Player of the Match):
"I'm quite used to seeing such pitches during the IPL, so I had a fair idea of what lengths would work for me. My focus was on keeping the ball away from the batters' arc to make it harder for them.

Bowling at Eden Gardens is always challenging, especially with every over bringing a new test. The last over, in particular, was very tough, but by God's grace, I managed to pull it off.

I can't rely on side spin to beat the batsmen—bounce is my primary weapon. That’s what I try to use to my advantage. I’d rate myself a 7 out of 10 at the moment; there’s still more work to do, and I’m committed to improving further."

India showcased their resilience and composure to secure a tense two-wicket victory over England in the second T20I at the MA Chidambaram Stadium, taking a 2-0 lead in the five-match series. Tilak Varma emerged as the hero of the night with a gritty unbeaten 72 off 55 balls, guiding the hosts to a challenging target of 166 on a tricky Chennai wicket.

Opting to bowl first, India’s bowlers once again delivered a disciplined performance, restricting England to 165/9 in their 20 overs. Varun Chakravarthy and Axar Patel were the standout performers with two wickets apiece, applying the brakes on England’s scoring. Jos Buttler anchored the innings with a crucial 45, while late fireworks from Brydon Carse and Jamie Smith added valuable runs to push England to a competitive total.

Chasing 166, India’s top order faltered on a surface offering assistance to the bowlers. However, Tilak Varma held his nerve, constructing a mature knock under pressure. Down the order, Washington Sundar chipped in with a crucial 26, adding vital runs in a tense chase. For England, Brydon Carse was the pick of the bowlers, finishing with impressive figures of 3/29, but his efforts weren’t enough to prevent India from crossing the line.

With this hard-fought victory, India now leads the series 2-0. England will need to regroup quickly to stay alive in the contest as the series heads to its third game.

Jos Buttler (England Skipper)
"Really competitive match. Full credit to Tilak's match-winning performance. Our aggressive approach created opportunities, kept them under pressure. Very satisfied with our batting intent - despite losing wickets, we maintained our attacking style. Jamie Smith's innings was outstanding. While there's room for improvement, we're committed to this approach."

Suryakymar Yadav (Indian Skipper)
"Target of 160 felt competitive and our bowling executed well. The extra batting depth who can bowl has worked for us. While we play aggressively, today's situation required smart batting - really impressed with Tilak's knock. Bishnoi and Arshdeep's batting contributions show their practice is paying off. Team's on the same page with our goals and approach, which is key to our success."

Tilak Varma (Player of The Match)
"On this two-paced wicket, I adapted my game following Gautam sir's advice about situational batting. The left-right combination with Bishnoi worked well, making it tricky for bowlers. Our South Africa experience and net practice prepared us well. I just told Bishnoi to maintain his shape and find gaps."

We want to continue playing our aggressive brand of cricket but adapt to the situation when required. From here on, we’re treating it like a three-match series. The boys are pumped and ready to give it their all tonight.We’ve made one change to the XI. Arshdeep Singh is resting, and Mohammed Shami is back."

 

Jos Buttler  | England Captain:
"It looks like an excellent surface, and we're looking forward to batting first. Yes, we would have preferred to chase, but it’s a good wicket, and the boys have prepared well. The last game was a fantastic contest, and we know we need to be at our absolute best to win tonight. India will come hard at us as usual, and we’re ready for the challenge. We’re playing the same team, with one change. Jamie Smith will keep wickets as Phil Salt is nursing a minor calf strain."

England secured a crucial 26-run win in the third T20I at the Niranjan Shah Stadium, Rajkot, to keep the series alive at 2-1. A strong all-round performance ensured the visitors bounced back after consecutive losses.Batting first, England posted 171/9 in their 20 overs. Ben Duckett led the charge with a blistering 51 off 28 balls, while Liam Livingstone smashed 43 off 24, including five sixes. Skipper Jos Buttler contributed a steady 24. Varun Chakravarthy was the standout bowler for India, picking up 5/24, and dismantling England’s middle and lower order. In reply, India struggled to maintain momentum on a flat track. Abhishek Sharma’s brisk 24 and Suryakumar Yadav’s quickfire 14 promised a solid start, but wickets fell at regular intervals. Hardik Pandya top-scored with a fighting 40 off 35, but lacked support as the middle-order faltered. Jamie Overton was England’s star with the ball, taking 3/24, while Jofra Archer and Brydon Carse chipped in with two wickets each. India managed 145/9, falling short by 26 runs. Despite the loss, the Men in Blue lead the series 2-1

 

Suryakumar Yadav | India Captain
"We expected some dew later, which is why we chose to bowl first. The game was in our hands when Hardik and Axar were batting, but credit to Adil Rashid—he bowled brilliantly and didn’t let us rotate the strike, showing why he’s world-class.Every T20 game teaches us something. We need to learn from our mistakes, especially in batting, and make adjustments. Shami will improve as he plays more, and Varun Chakravarthy’s hard work is paying off with fantastic results on the field. We’ll regroup and aim to bounce back stronger in the next game." 
 

Jos Buttler | England Captain
"The guys bowled well today, showcasing their skills not just with pace but also by adapting to the conditions.Adil Rashid is, without a doubt, the most important player in our team. His variations are incredible, and we’re lucky to have him. Jofra Archer, even if he goes for 60, always bounces back stronger—he’s just that good.Duckett was brilliant; once he gets going, he’s hard to stop. The wicket behaved differently than expected, but I think 170 was a competitive score.I loved the way we kept taking the game on. Credit to Adil and Mark Wood for adding those crucial 20 runs for the last wicket—it made all the difference in the end. Overall, a great effort from the team to stay alive in the series."

Player of the Match: Varun Chakaravarthy 
"Unfortunately we couldn't win this match, but that’s the nature of the game. We have to move on and focus on the next one.Playing for the country means taking responsibility, and I’m glad I’ve been able to do that to an extent. I’m always prepared for any situation, whether it’s bowling four overs on the trot or adapting to different roles.I’ve been working on my flipper, and it’s coming out well. As I mentioned earlier, there’s always room to improve, and I’ll keep striving to get better."
